Headline: Barron's(7/16) Streetwise: Why The Skeptics May Be Wrong
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Records were made to be argued over, which is why they provide lasting fun. You can still raise the blood pressure of an entire bar, 66 summers later, by whispering that DiMaggio's hit streak is breakable.   So let's handicap the current argument over the impressive though far less momentous records set by the popular stock indexes last week, which came from a sudden 2% jump on Thursday.   A vocal klatch of market commentators wants to place an asterisk next to this record, insisting it shows neglect of much evident and fearsome bad news, came on so-so trading volume and represents a speculative gambit fueled by debt and hope.   Well, not exactly. This column has been highlighting in recent weeks investors' outsized attention to several prominent negatives, amid what appeared to be an excess of hedging and shorting, given that the market was all of a couple of percent from all-time highs. This dynamic remains more or less in place.   Last week nicely illustrated how welled-up anxiety often gives way to a quicksilver rally. The debt market was starting to attach strings to buyout financing, oil prices were levitating, bank stocks were ominously weak and the Standard & Poor's conference call to discuss a mass downgrade of subprime securities literally exceeded the telecom host's capacity to service all the interested listeners.   Oh, and the Homeland Security boss mentioned that he had a tickle in his gut telling him another terrorist attack was likely this summer. Yes, there was plenty to worry about, and investors were plenty worried.   Meantime, the commercial dealers who represent the smarter money are more long S&P 500 index futures than they've been in years. Company insiders have radically slowed their selling. There has been a high base of shorted stock, up 30% from January through mid-June (though it's unclear how much might have been unwound in the rally).   The bears argue that short-interest levels are less meaningful because the proliferation of hedge funds and newly trendy "130/30 funds," which keep 30% short positions to fund new longs, are "structural" changes. To a degree, yes. But what does it say about sentiment that in the fifth year of a bull market the vogue strategy is to morph long-only accounts into long-short funds?   Some $375 billion in cash takeovers are due to close in the next 90 days, most of the money going to fund managers who mechanically redeposit cash in different stocks. Private-equity funds raised another $137 billion in the first half, says Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst, up 42% from a year ago.   Doubters last week were raising another point of argument, that just-released data showed margin borrowing in May at an all-time high of $353 billion, above its peak early-2000 level and up 11% from April. But taking a fuller view of investor finances, netting out freely available cash balances in NYSE accounts shows net margin debt of $68 billion.   Also, recent regulatory changes in a pilot program have let clients at eight firms -- mostly prime brokers who serve hedge funds -- raise borrowing capacity by counting a client's whole portfolio as collateral, rather than just the securities bought on margin.   This might be viewed as reckless in the long term, and it does represent a form of "greater fool" investing, yet for a time it will allow for further leveraging of those copious free-cash balances as the program widens.   This all says nothing about the direction of the next few percent. Huge record-setting rallies tend to wipe away a lot of constructive skepticism, and there's emerging a bit too much frothy options speculation and rumor-mongering.   And let's not forget that all the U.S. market is doing is participating -- as a laggard, no less -- in a global lift in asset values, as expressed in ever-weaker dollars. The S&P 500 is up 9.5% this year, while the Dow Jones World Ex-U.S. index is up 15%.   But if -- if -- this bull market is ultimately to overshoot the way prior ones have, the public will have to get more excited, the bear ranks must shrink, the buyouts need to get even sillier, and indexes likely higher.     In March, as noted here, ardor had cooled a bit for energy stocks, which made neglected giants ConocoPhilips (ticker: COP) and Chevron (CVX) look attractive. Today the speculators love crude, the commercial dealers are short it and those two stocks are up 32% and 22% in four months. This bull market in oil might be due for one of its periodic retreats.   To chase crude or the stocks here means betting on a hurricane or some geopolitical scare. Both are plausible, but it's tough to have an edge. Not a bad place to take profits.   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) The Trader: Wall Street Shops At Its Own Mall Of America
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Shopping is everything from an economic transaction to a national recreation, but even that may understate its considerable charms.   For Americans squeezed by higher gas prices and lower home values, shopping is both diversion and therapy -- and they did it often enough to help retailers report a 2.4% rise in June sales. Companies were at it, too, and even fought over the same merchandise, with the global-miner Rio Tinto (ticker: RTP) coughing up $38 billion to snatchthe aluminum-company Alcan (AL) away from rival Alcoa (AA).   Traders groping for direction saw all that buying as evidence that economic growth likely will persist, and as corroboration for the notion that stocks might be undervalued, and that inspired them to do some buying of their own.   Stocks jumped Thursday in one of their fiercest one-day rallies in years. A 9.6% profit rise reported by General Electric (GE) Friday helped the market hold onto its gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed for the third straight week and gained 296, or 2.2%, to 13,907, its 29th record close this year. The Standard & Poor's 500 added 22, or 1.4%, to 1553, also a record. The Nasdaq Composite Index rallied 40, or 1.5%, to 2707, its highest finish in 6 1/2 years, while the Russell 2000 crept up 3, or 0.4%, to 856.   Buying is, of course, just another word for spending, and lately it's the sustainability of America's debt-driven spending that has worried the market. Those concerns drove the Dow down nearly 150 points as recently as Tuesday, as companies like Home Depot (HD) and Sears (SHLD) blamed a still weakening housing market for their glum forecasts. But each passing day without a new catastrophe from the mortgage world encourages the restless bulls, as does the recent stabilization of the 10-year Treasury yield just above 5%.   The credit market behind private equity's buying spree also has behaved. A few recent buyouts have had to rely on bridge loans for financing, but deals -- for now -- are still completed with no more than minor tweaks. Last week, buyers that had offered $25 billion for Sallie Mae, or SLM (SLM), balked, although their remorse likely was company specific and tied to proposed legislation that could slash government subsidies for student loans.   How persuasive was last week's surge? Volume was strong in Thursday's rally, and was swelled by short covering as the indexes swerved higher after Tuesday's slide. The blue-chips' violent rise also was matched by the Dow Transportation Average.   So staunch is the market's belief in this liquidity boom that these days no chatter is deemed too outlandish and no target too big. Last week, shares of Unilever (UN), Lazard (LAZ), Black & Decker (BDK) and Hovnanian (HOV) all ran up on speculation that they have attracted, respectively, the attentions of Colgate-Palmolive (CL), a European bank, an industrial conglomerate, and Warren Buffett.   Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates sees hints of a "bubble mentality" that bears watching, or what he calls the Annie ("The sun will come out tomorrow") Syndrome. "Historically, when a company in a sector is taken out, the others move slightly," he notes. "Today, if one stock goes, the other names rise almost proportionately."   Bulls argue, quite rightly, that stock-market tops seldom form amid so much worry and such record short bets. But debt-market red flags can still thwart stocks' jumpy advance.   Last week, crude oil climbed to an 11-month high at $73.93. Canada and Korea raised interest rates, and the dollar sunk to a new low against the euro. That's bad news for Americans shopping along Via Della Spiga, but a potential boost for U.S. exports.   "A 10% decline in the dollar typically means an additional 1.5 percentage points to year-over-year S&P 500 earnings growth," says Morgan Stanley's William Smith, although not all sectors benefit equally. Large caps, with nearly 40% of revenue derived overseas, reap the most gains, as do the energy, materials, industrials and technology companies.     It is perhaps inevitable that Target (TGT), that temple for mass consumerism, should find itself on Bill Ackman's shopping list. Pershing Square Capital, the hedge fund Ackman manages, has accumulated Target shares and options worth nearly $6 billion and is preparing a regulatory filing detailing its stake.   Target shares jumped 10% this month as first rumors and then reports pointed to the activist-investor's interest. "We hadn't considered a retailer that executes as consistently and excellently as Target to be, well, a target," says the bond-analysis firm Gimme Credit. "But naturally a company that strives to maintain a strong balance sheet and prudent credit measures could always be pressured to leverage up to return more cash to its shareholders."   Hear that? In a market where liquidity is plenteous but value scarce, fewer companies are safe from the attentions of restive investors. The fixer-uppers have been picked over, and hedge funds' cross-hairs increasingly are trained on the unbroken but under-levered.   What might Target expect with Ackman's attention? Pershing Square previously amassed positions in companies like McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's International (WEN) and then pressed management to improve profits.   Among other things, Ackman might broach the sale of Target's credit-card operation, which has $6.5 billion in receivables. Its contribution to earnings growth is slight, but management has maintained it is integral to building brand loyalty and tracking spending habits.   Target might also be prodded to sell and then lease back its real estate. The Minneapolis company has some of the choicest retail locations, and the value of those properties presumably is understated on its balance sheet. It has been suggested the real estate could be worth nearly a third of Target's $70 billion in enterprise value. But while a sale and leaseback could raise billions, the ensuing rent expense could cut cash flow by almost $2 billion.   Levering up is another option, but with shares at an all-time peak, it remains to be seen if management can be talked into a move that some estimate would boost per-share earnings by less than 10%.   Target shares have risen 54% over the past year to trade near 70. While sales have suffered as gas prices climbed, the retailer still outshines rivals like Wal-Mart (WMT), whose slower growth and unwieldy international sprawl might eventually prove more worthy of shareholder agitation.   If Ackman proves right on the dot, two things at the very least are clear: Target shares straining record highs might still offer good value, and widespread worries of consumer retreat may not prove as dire as many feared. It has become a recurring theme of this bull run: Americans will shop till they drop.     It's a rather moist mystery. The company in question, Mueller Water Products (MWA), makes things like hydrants, valves and pipes used in water distribution and treatment. Because its two classes of common stock control similar economic interest, they have always traded in tight tandem -- until last month, when they curiously began to diverge.   By Thursday, Mueller's A shares were worth about 16.41. But the super-voting B shares -- each giving eight votes to just one for the A shares -- were at 14.53.   What gives?   Mueller's Class A shares made their debut in May 2006 when nearly 29 million were sold to the public, while its former parent, Walter Industries (WLT), held onto Class B shares and controlled 96% of the voting power. But by December, Walter had distributed all the B shares to its stockholders. Since then, the two classes have been inseparable on a stock chart.   Then came June, when Mueller's A shares -- but not the B -- were triumphantly added to the Russell 2000 index. Quickly, the gap between A and B shares widened from 1% or 2% to the current 11.5% chasm.   How are the two classes different? The company's own Website declares they "have identical rights in all material respects" except for the B shares' superior voting power. The A shares are slightly more liquid, but their marginally higher trading volume had existed long before the recent divergence.   "Apparently, indexing has created and sustained an inefficiency we'd think would be arbitraged away in today's ultra-competitive markets," says Michael Econn, a co-manager at Bondurant Management. Going against the flow, the New York hedge fund sold the A shares it held and bought the discounted B shares, essentially counting on the gap closing once the index-related gush subsides.     Migraines, according to the National Library of Medicine, can be triggered by bright lights, loud noises, weather changes, smoke, perfumes, alcohol, caffeine, red wine, aged cheese, smoked fish, bacon, chocolates, nuts, avocado, bananas, onions ...you get the idea. Over the past year, 18% of U.S. women and 6% of men have suffered at least one attack.   So it's easy to see why shares of a little-known drug-development company, Pozen (POZN), have run up 16% since June. Pozen has developed with GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) a tablet for treating migraines, and a regulatory decision regarding the remedy, known as Trexima, is expected Aug. 1.   Option prices suggest that the market sees a 60% chance Trexima will be approved by the Food and Drug Administration, but Citigroup analyst Lucy Lu is more optimistic. She pegs the odds of an FDA nod at 80%, given Trexima's superior efficacy results in clinical trials and a safety profile comparable to Imitrex, currently the go-to drug with 55% of the U.S. market. Imitrex already is a winner for GlaxoSmithKline.   Lu believes a yes could drive Pozen shares, trading at 18.50 recently, to between 23 and 25 and towards her 12-month target of 28. "We believe Trexima will be the new gold standard treatment of migraine headaches," she notes.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from July 5 through July 12.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Bioenvision (BIVN)   SCO Capital Partners has sent a sixth letter to Bioenvision proposing a "new plan" for the company and its shareholders, who recently rejected a $5.60-a-share takeover by Genzyme (GENZ). SCO said that it wants to fill two of the seats on Bioenvision's board, stabilize and augment management, and terminate Genzyme's North American sublicense to produce clofarabine, an anti-cancer substance.   Despite the rejection of the tender offer, Genzyme is still purchasing 22% of the company and is hoping for a full merger vote by the end of the year. SCO Capital Partners holds 7.21 million shares (13.4%).     Cryo-Cell International (CCEL)   Partner Community has nominated six candidates for election to the board. Four of these nominees, David I. Portnoy, Mark L. Portnoy, Scott D. Martin and Craig E. Fleishman, collectively hold a 4.6% stake in the Oldsmar, Fla., blood-bank operator. Partner Community said that the four have verbally agreed to vote all of each nominee's shares for the election of the six candidates. Partner Community owns 90,787 shares (0.07%).     Advanced Medical Optics (EYE)   ValueAct Capital will vote against the company's bid for rival Bausch & Lomb (BOL), saying the deal is too risky. ValueAct said the company should focus on fixing its contact lens-solution business and integrating prior acquisitions before bidding for Bausch & Lomb. ValueAct Capital holds 8,811,635 shares (14.7%).     Vitesse Semiconductor (VTSS)   Chapman Capital demanded that the company announce by July 31 either the scheduling of an annual shareholders meeting or the appointment of at least two shareholder-selected directors. Robert L. Chapman, the managing member of Chapman Capital, said "an owner-led board reconstitution was imperative and long overdue." Chapman Capital has about 14 million shares (6.4%).     ESS Technology (ESST)   Loeb Partners believes the company has only two viable options: a sale or a liquidation on a "timely and cost-effective basis." Loeb said that it may engage in talks with ESS or seek representation on its board if a sale or liquidation isn't "pursued vigorously." In mid-June, ESS said directors on the board's strategic-transaction committee would look into liquidation as part of a review of corporate alternatives. Loeb Partners owns about 3.14 million shares (8.83%).     Original Filings     TransAlta (TAC)   Luminus Management reported ownership of 13.52 million shares (6.7%), bought from May 1 to July 6 at prices ranging from $23.67 to $28.31.     Increases in Holdings     Borders Group (BGP)   Spencer Capital Management boosted its holdings to 4,008,101 shares (6.8%) by buying 2,358,901 from June 21 to July 2 at $19.05 to $19.81 per share.     W.P. Stewart (WPL)   Van Den Berg Management raised its stake to 11.95 million shares (25.1%) from the 11.61 million (24.4%) reported on July 2.     Decreases in Holdings     Carmike Cinemas (CKEC)   Fine Capital Partners cut it stake to 567,600 shares (4.5%), selling 77,000 from June 11 to July 6 at $21.74 to $26.03 apiece.     EXCO Resources (XCO)   Director T. Boone Pickens trimmed his position to 11 million shares (10.5%) by selling 623,233 on July 5 and 6 at an average price of $18.03 (see page M13).     Openwave Systems (OPWV)   A group including Harbinger Capital Partners Master Fund I reduced its holdings to 7.94 million shares (9.6%) by selling 1.17 million from June 29 to July 5. The sales were done at prices ranging from $6.20 to $6.29.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japanese Prosecutors Drop Charges Vs 3 Toyota Execs -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (AP)--Prosecutors have dropped charges against three Toyota executives who were under investigation on suspicion of avoiding recalls and contributing to an accident, the Nikkei reported Saturday.   Prosecutors in western Kumamoto prefecture formally dropped the charges Friday after deciding they lacked sufficient evidence to move ahead with professional negligence charges in the 2004 head-on crash, The Nikkei said.   "If we can't say that the accident was directly connected with not carrying out the recall, then there is no negligence that merits imposing criminal penalties against these three officials," the paper quoted assistant chief prosecutor Seiji Sakizaka as saying.   Toyota has denied wrongdoing in the case.   Prosecutors' office officials could not immediately be reached Saturday afternoon. Phones rang unanswered at Toyota.   Five people were injured in 2004 when the steering failed in a Toyota Hilux Surf sport utility vehicle, causing it to swing out of control into the wrong lane, police said.   At the center of the investigation was whether Toyota had avoided making a needed recall for eight years. Company officials were accused of being aware of the steering problem as far back as 1995 or 1996, with reports of problems initially surfacing in 1992.   Toyota did not carry out a recall on the model until October 2004. The recall was for a problem part used in the steering that could break, according to Toyota.   Prosecutors took over a police investigation last year that accused the three officials overseeing quality control at the automaker. Their names have not been disclosed, and Toyota has said at least one of them has left the company.   Toyota has a strong reputation for impeccable quality, but that image has been dented a bit lately due to series of recalls, which have raised some doubts whether it can maintain quality standards as its global sales expand rapidly.   Toyota executives have repeatedly expressed concerns about sliding quality and have promised to strengthen quality controls.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 03:24 ET (07:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) The New Way To Retire
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Daisy Maxey   Weddings of long-term care insurance and annuities are about to heat up.   The Pension Protection Act of 2006 has clarified the tax treatment of annuities and other insurance products when they are combined with long-term care insurance, and that is spurring innovation in the industry. The law will make some hybrid products more attractive, and, although its tax provision doesn't kick in until Jan. 1, 2010, insurers are already revising existing products and launchingnew ones.   One attractive combo product, called the life-care annuity, would provide regular income and, if needed, cover long-term care.   "Quite a few life insurers are looking at it," says Alane Dent, a vice president for the American Council of Life Insurers.   The life-care annuity was envisioned several years ago by Mark Warshawsky, now director of retirement research at consulting firm Watson Wyatt Worldwide; Brenda Spillman, an economist at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit Washington research institute; and Christopher Murtaugh, associate director for the New York-based Center for Home Care Policy and Research, a research center established by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.   Their idea was an annuity that, for a single premium payment, would provide a steady income to a retired household, and increase significantly upon disability to cover any necessary long-term-care expenses.   That eliminates one of the big deterrents to the purchase of long-term care insurance -- the fear among consumers that they may pay into a policy over a lifetime, never use it and lose their investment.   For instance, a 65-year-old might pay a premium of $156,000 for $1,000 a month in income for life plus a monthly disability payment of at least $2,000 a month when needed, Murtaugh, Spillman and Warshawsky estimated in a 2001 study. They figured that as much as 98% of the population of 65-year-olds could be able to pass the minimal underwriting and be eligible for the product.   Life-care annuities could also be cheaper than an income annuity and long-term care disability coverage purchased separately because they would pool two very different risk groups, Warshawsky says.   Consumers who expect longer-than-average life spans tend to purchase annuities, while those who expect shorter-than-average life spans, and would therefore face disability sooner, cannot purchase long-term-care insurance because of strict underwriting standards. Those tendencies raise the risks for insurers, and boost costs. The life-care annuity would attract both groups, combining those opposing risk pools, which would lower the cost and minimize the need for medical underwriting for disability coverage, he says.   While such products are starting to be offered now, they will become considerably more attractive when the tax provisions take effect in three years, Warshawsky suggests. So folks approaching retirement could do well to keep an eye on the developing market.   Right now, if a consumer buys long-term care insurance under a "qualified" contract, benefits are generally considered to be accident and health insurance and are thus tax-free. But such qualified contracts generally may not provide a cash value.   Under provisions of the pension act that go into effect Jan. 1, 2010, however, withdrawals from certain annuities intended to pay for specific, tax-qualified long-term-care insurance will not be considered taxable income. In addition, the act will allow those in a qualified life-insurance or annuity contract to exchange such contracts for long-term-care insurance contracts tax-free.   "If you decide you don't need the life or annuity protection, this would allow you to exchange that policy for a long-term care policy to help prefund some of your long-term care needs," says Malcolm Cheung, vice president of long-term care insurance at Prudential Financial. "That would be a major advantage for consumers."   Insurers are clearly intrigued by the prospects. They are starting to roll out new versions of life-care annuities, aimed at consumers who want the benefits of the instruments and are willing to forgo the tax breaks for three years.   In the third quarter of this year, Richmond, Va.-based Genworth Financial (ticker: GNW) plans to introduce the Total Living Coverage Annuity, which combines a single-premium deferred annuity and a long-term-care contract. The product has been approved in 30 states, and the company has done pilot sales in about six states, says Beth Ludden, senior vice president of product development for long-term-care insurance at Genworth. The firm is currently working on another version of the product that will specifically take advantage of the act's provisions and appeal to individuals who are already in an annuity product and want long-term care coverage.   State Life Insurance, an Indianapolis affiliate of OneAmerica Financial Partners, has updated its Annuity Care product to take advantage of provisions of the Pension Protection Act. The product, a deferred annuity, was introduced in 1997. It allows access to the annuity's cash value for qualifying long-term care expenses, with a higher credited interest rate for these funds. It also offers an option that provides lifetime long-term care coverage.   Louisiana-based Guaranty Income Life Insurance has been selling its AnnuiCare product, a tax-deferred annuity that also provides long-term care benefits, since 1999, says President John H. Lancaster. The Pension Protection Act tax changes will allow premiums for the long-term-care, he says, to be paid from untaxed annuity distributions and the long-term care benefits paid will be tax free.   "It's a huge market and a great opportunity," says Lancaster. The company is now on track to sell $14 million of its AnnuiCare product in 2007, versus $7 million in 2006, Lancaster says. "It's all building up to 2010 when all the benefits kick in."   Though consumers who purchase such products now don't benefit from the added benefits of the Pension Protection Act until 2010, the discussion around the act has prompted more attention and interest in the products, says Lancaster.   Lincoln National Life Insurance, an affiliate of Lincoln Financial Group, has offered MoneyGuard, a combination life insurance and long-term-care policy since 1998. The Pension Protection Act has brought life to the annuity/long-term care product, says Mark Doherty, MoneyGuard's business leader. Lincoln National has such a product which has been approved in a number of states.   Says Bruce Moon, vice president for marketing at State Life: "I really think you're going to see a lot more of these types of products available to consumers between now and Jan. 1, 2010." Moon, whose company helped draft the legislation, says the tax clarification is sure to lead to better ways to convert annuity dollars to pay for long-term care.   Some bigger players are eyeing the market closely. Prudential Financial (PRU), MetLife (MET), for instance, both say they are evaluating the combination vehicles.   Certainly, Americans need to do more to save for their retirement and long-term health-care needs. Medicare and Medicaid paid for more than 60% of the nation's nursing home and home health services in 2005, according to the federal Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and the pending retirement of tens of millions of baby boomers is set to strain federal and state governments even further.   With many defined-benefit plans giving retirees the option to take their benefits either as an annuity or as a lump sum, and with defined-contribution plans, which typically offer no annuitization choice, becoming more popular, retirees need more efficient retirement savings vehicles, says Warshawsky.   Life-care annuities would eventually work well as an optional distribution mechanism from qualified retirement plans, Warshawsky says. That would require changes to Treasury and Internal Revenue Service regulations and maybe the law, and would be dictated by demand for the product, he says.   Life-care annuities "could be the next big product innovation for insurers," says Terence Martin, vice president of Hartford-based Conning Research & Consulting. And though he doubts the vehicles will solve Medicare's woes, they won't hurt, either. Says Martin: "Every little bit helps."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: GCap Considers Opting Out Of Digital Radio - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--GCap Media PLC (GCAP.LN), the U.K.'s largest listed radio company, has warned it may have to pull out of digital radio if it does not see faster technology growth and get a commitment from regulators to switch off analog signals, the Financial Times reported Saturday.   Citing Chief Executive Ralph Bernard, the paper said GCap was mulling switching off analog AM stations voluntarily, provided it made financial sense.   Bernard said that unless significant progress was made in pushing digital penetration higher and getting a switchover date, GCap Media would have to consider whether it would be financially more prudent to pull out of digital, the newspaper reported.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 08:34 ET (12:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 2nd UPDATE: China Bans Food Products From Tyson, Other US Cos
Story: (Updates with comment from Tyson Foods)     BEIJING (AP)--China has suspended imports of from Tyson Foods Inc. (TSN) and several other U.S. meat processors, in an apparent attempt to turn the tables on U.S. complaints about tainted products from China.   China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine late Friday said frozen poultry from Springdale, Ark.-based Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest meat processor, was contaminated with salmonella.   Frozen chicken feet from Laurel, Miss.-based Sanderson Farms Inc. (SAFM) were tainted with residue of an anti-parasite drug, and frozen pork ribs from Wichita, Kan.-based Cargill Meat Solutions Corp. contained the leanness-enhancing feed additive ractopamine, the agency said.   Frozen pig ears from Kansas City, Mo.-based Van Luin Foods USA Inc. were found to contain ractopamine. Frozen chicken feet from Atlanta-based Intervision Foods was tainted with salmonella, and frozen pork from Atlanta's AJC International Inc. was tainted with ractopamine, the agency said.   Both stewed chicken feet and pig ears are popular dishes in China.   Sausage casing from a seventh company, listed by the Chinese agency as "Thumph Foods," was also found to contain ractopamine, according to the Chinese agency. It wasn't clear whether it was referring to Triumph Foods of St. Joseph, Mo.   Mark Klein, a spokesman for Minneapolis-based Cargill Inc., disputed the Chinese inspectors' findings that his company's products were tainted and said Cargill hoped to resolve the issue by working with U.S. and Chinese officials.   "We're proud of our products and our processes, and we'll be delighted to talk about them with all concerned," he said.   Cargill is the parent company of Cargill Meat Solutions Corp., which as of 2005 was the ninth leading pork producer in the U.S., according to the National Pork Producers Council.   Libby Lawson, a spokeswoman for Tyson Foods, said the company knew nothing about any tainted product.   "We're disappointed with this news from China and are investigating these claims as this is the first we've heard of this development," she said. "We have received no notice from the Chinese government about this matter. We will work with the U.S. and Chinese government to get this matter resolved."   Officials with the other companies couldn't immediately be reached for comment.   Although China supplies most of its own meat, its imports of foreign meat are growing. A contagious disease has killed tens of thousands of pigs in China this year, and many farmers have stopped raising pigs because of worries they would lose money if the animals die. As a result, prices of pork - the country's staple meat - have shot up 43%, a jump so serious that China's Cabinet held an emergency session and Premier Wen Jiabao made public appearances to address concerns.   Cargill, Van Luin and "Thumph Foods" were given 45 days to correct the contamination problems, while the others were suspended from imports, though China didn't say for how long.   It was also unclear whether the bans covered only the products in question, or all of the companies' imports.   A duty officer reached by phone at the Chinese agency Saturday said he didn't know details.   Beijing has taken steps in recent days to improve the image of its products. It executed the former head of its drug regulation agency for taking bribes, and banned toothpaste makers from using a chemical found in antifreeze.   Officials also have vowed to better integrate China's fractured regulatory system, which splits responsibility among at least six agencies. Blurred lines between them often enable the country's countless illegal operations to escape detection.   The official Xinhua News Agency quoted Li Yuanping, director of the Chinese agency's import and export bureau, as saying China's government has thoroughly investigated each case of substandard exports.   "All of them are exceptional cases," he said in the Saturday report, adding that more than 99% of China's exports meets standards. "China-made products should not be labeled as substandard just because of a few bad producers."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 13:59 ET (17:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Iraqi Translator For Reuters News Agency Killed By Gunmen
Story: BAGHDAD (AP)--An Iraqi translator for Reuters was shot to death by gunmen, an apparent victim of sectarian death squads, the third employee of the news agency killed in Baghdad this week, Reuters reported on Saturday.   The London-based news agency did not identify the translator at the request of relatives, apparently to avoid publicizing the family's link to the company. The announcement of his death came a day after an Iraqi journalist for The New York Times was killed by gunmen.   The 30-year-old translator was killed Wednesday while driving with two of his brothers in southeast Baghdad, an area where Shiite and Sunni militants operate.   "It appears the killing was one of the dozens of executions carried out every day in Baghdad by sectarian death squads that roam the city despite the presence of some 100,000 U.S. and Iraqi security forces in the city," the agency said in its report on his death.   The staffer usually took Thursday and Friday off, so Reuters became concerned when he did not come to work on Saturday, it said. He had been working for the agency since March and was married with two young daughters, it said.   He was the seventh Reuters employee to be killed in the Iraqi conflict, including an Iraqi photographer and driver - Namir Noor-Eldeen and driver Saeed Chmagh - who died Thursday during a clash between U.S. forces and Shiite militiamen.   The Times reporter, Khalid W. Hassan, was killed by gunmen as he drove to work Friday morning in southern Baghdad.   The latest Reuters death brings to 151 the number of journalists and media support staffers - the majority of them Iraqis - killed since the 2003 U.S. invasion, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 11:46 ET (15:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China Bans Products From Tyson, Other US Cos On Safety Fears
Story: BEIJING (AP)--China has suspended imports of some frozen products from Tyson Foods Inc. (TSN) and several other U.S. companies - the latest indication that China may be retaliating as its products are turned back from overseas because of safety concerns.   Frozen poultry products from Tyson, the world's largest meat processor, were found to be contaminated with salmonella, according to a list posted late Friday on the Web site of China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine.   Other imports barred by China included frozen chicken feet from Sanderson Farms, Inc. (SAFM) found to tainted with residue of an anti-parasite drug, as well as frozen pork ribs from Cargill Meat Solutions Corp. containing a leanness-enhancing feed additive, the agency said.   China's food- and drug safety has come under scrutiny in recent months following the deaths of cats and dogs in the United States and Canada blamed on tainted Chinese pet food ingredients. Worries at home and around the world have heightened as a growing number of Chinese products are found tainted with dangerous levels of toxins.   Beijing has taken significant steps in recent days to clean up its product safety record, including executing the former head of its drug regulation agency for taking bribes, and banning the use of a chemical found in antifreeze in the production of toothpaste.   Officials have also vowed to better integrate its fractured regulatory system, which currently splits responsibility among at least six agencies. The blurred lines often enable the country's countless illegal operations to escape detection.   As China works to improve food safety, authorities have also prominently announced rejections of imports, apparently to turn the tables on critics and show it is not the only country with food export safety problems.   It was not clear whether the latest import bans covered only the products in question or if they extended to all of the companies' imports. A duty officer at the AQSIQ on Saturday said he did not know any details.   Mark Klein, a spokesman for Minneapolis-based Cargill Inc., disputed the Chinese inspectors' findings and said the company hoped to resolve the issue by working with U.S. and Chinese officials.   "We're proud of our products and our processes," Klein said, "and we'll be delighted to talk about them with all concerned."   Cargill is the parent company of Wichita, Kansas-based Cargill Meat Solutions Corp., the second-largest beef processor in the U.S.   Messages seeking comment were left with two spokesmen for Springdale, Ark.-based Tyson, the world's largest meat processor. A voicemail seeking comment was left at Sanderson Farms Inc., based in Laurel, Miss.   Beijing has previously rejected shipments of substandard orange pulp, dried apricots, raisins and health supplements from the U.S.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 02:24 ET (06:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Barron's Online: Hey, Sport, Here's A Stock For You
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alexander Eule   Daktronics and its massive video scoreboards have had little trouble gaining the appreciation of sports fans.   But when it comes to investors, it's been a different story for the South Dakota-based maker of electronic advertising displays and stadium scoreboards.   Since briefly trading above $40 last December, Daktronics' shares (ticker: DAKT), had fallen 41%, as of Thursday, as a result of revenue shortfalls due to delayed orders. Over the past 12 months, the stock is off about 15%, versus a gain around 23% for the S&P 500.     For a patient investor, however, there could be a great deal of upside in Daktronics, thanks to new stadium construction and evolving billboard technology. The company enjoys a 70% share of the major-stadium scoreboard business and 50% of the nascent market for digital advertising billboards.   Analysts expect the company to earn $1.04 a share in 2009, according to Thomson Financial, almost double the 59 cents reported for fiscal 2007.   Founded in 1968 as a maker of electronic voting systems for state legislatures, Daktronics trades at a forward price-to-earnings-to-earnings-growth ratio of 1.1 -- 16% below its five-year average. "I know that there's a big tidal wave of opportunity coming," says Michael Alpert, managing director and portfolio manager of the J. & W. Seligman Small Company Growth Team.   In 2006, construction began on a record $4 billion-worth of arenas and stadiums, according to McGraw-Hill Construction. The previous record was $3 billion in 1997.   Craig-Hallum Capital Group analyst Steve Dyer estimates that spending will total more than $14 billion for major college and professional sports facilities opening between now and 2010 -- a notable uptick, he says, from the total in the past three or four years.   Additionally, the need to differentiate the live-sports experience from advancing living-room technology is putting entertainment displays at the forefront of stadium plans and construction. "They've become a part of the architecture of the stadium," Daktronics CEO Jim Morgan tells Barron's Online.   Morgan says that Daktronics' new major stadium projects are worth "north of $10 million," with some in the $20 million range.   For their new football stadium, scheduled to open in 2009, the Dallas Cowboys envision multiple video displays, including two that will be 180 feet long and 50 feet high -- 2,244 diagonal inches, or 53 times the size of a 42-inch flat-panel TV. No contract has yet been signed, but Daktronics is a frontrunner to build the 180-foot display. The screen would be Daktronics' largest, but Morgan says that larger ones are possible, using the company's light-emitting-diode (LED) technology. "We're only limited in size by the budget and physical constraints of the building," he maintains.   Alpert believes that the Cowboys' project could be worth $30 million to $40 million. Craig-Hallum's Dyer says that Daktronics is an obvious choice and calls the project "theirs to lose."     In fact, Daktronics' leading market share makes it the top candidate to win most of the pending stadium contracts. According to Alpert, Daktronics has garnered nine of the past 14 National Football League stadium deals. Three of the other five winners have since exited the market, including Sony (SNE) and its Jumbotron display. Mitsubishi, the Japanese conglomerate, is the largest remaining competitor.   Upgrade demand is also helping Daktronics, with operators of existing stadiums striving to meet or surpass the emerging high-definition standard. "We call it the 'Keeping up with the Joneses' effect," Morgan observes.   Best of all from investors' point of view, even though Daktronics' sport division has exceptional promise, its growth could trail that of the company's commercial business.   Just 560 of the approximately 342,000 billboards in the U.S. are digital, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.   However, the nation's two largest billboard companies, Lamar Advertising (LAMR) and Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings (CCO), are quickly increasing their inventory of digital displays. Lamar plans to have at least 600 by the end of the year, up from 428 as of May, while Clear Channel hopes to deploy 100 in 2007.     Digital boards are what advertisers love: attention grabbers. A recent Morgan Stanley report suggests that Lamar's digital boards are producing six to 12 times the revenue of static billboards.   Still, as Daktronics' lagging stock suggests, investors remain concerned about the pace of earnings growth at the company and the inherent lumpiness of a business that's partially driven by special projects.   Additionally, there's no guarantee that the company will continue to dominate large stadium deals, and regulatory hurdles could curtail the rollout of digital billboards. Some communities view the electronic signs as visual pollution; others consider them too distracting to motorists.   Lamar, however, believes that progress is being made on the regulatory front. The Outdoor Advertising Association is promoting a study that suggests that there is no relationship between the presence of digital billboards and the rate of traffic accidents.   Alpert says that Daktronics' uneven quarter-to-quarter performance shouldn't distract investors from the company's long-term potential. "It's very hard to find close to a monopoly business with huge demand opportunity," he says. "The only issue is: Some investors aren't patient enough to wait."   With new stadiums opening around the country, patient Daktronics investors eventually could be cheering louder than Cowboys fans did in the glory days of Troy Aikman, Emmitt Smith and Michael Irvin.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) In India, Internet Shares Hardly Come Cheap
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   In a world mad for Internet stocks, some of the maddest valuations have gone to two Internet companies in India that trade on Nasdaq, Rediff.com India (ticker: REDF), India's third largest portal, and Sify (SIFY), India's largest nongovernment-owned provider of broadband access.   With a market cap of $740 million, Rediff today trades at 115 times trailing earnings and 88 times forward earnings, while Sify, with a market value of $440 million (including $53 million in cash), sells at a trailing P/E of 205 and a forward multiple of 60. Andrew Foster, head of research at Matthews International Capital Management in San Francisco, owns Sify (he sold his Rediff shares long ago) and is enthusiastic about the sector, but he feels that "the listed companies may not be the best representatives" and "it's hard to find active ideas to endorse."   Bulls on the industry argue its growth prospects are huge, noting that just 18 of every 1,000 Indians have access to personal computers. The two companies' stock jumped even higher last week on news that Rediff may list its shares in India and is launching a YouTube-like content-sharing program, and that Sify would offer cybercafe subscribers access and training for Microsoft Office software.   Shares of Rediff, whose fans have dubbed it "the Google of the Ganges," have also been buoyed by frequent rumors that Google (GOOG) or Yahoo! (YHOO) might buy the company. But beneath all the cheering are serious doubts about Rediff's valuation, many of them based on comparisons of the company's market cap with the size of its main source of revenue.   The online Indian advertising market totaled $57 million in the year ended March, Kaufman Brothers estimates, which puts Rediff's value at 13 times the size of that market. Looked at another way, its market value is 27 times the $27 million in ad revenue for this year, a 67% gain, forecast by Ashish Thadhani of Gilford Securities, the sole analyst covering Rediff. Thadhani reckons that for the full year, total revenue will rise to $42.3 million from $28.7 million. That puts Rediff at 17 times sales.   In addition, Rediff's grip on its market seems to be slipping as Google and Yahoo! make inroads in India. In contrast, China's Baidu.com (BIDU), another expensive Internet stock, is gaining share in China. According to proprietary data from industry tracker comScore obtained by Barron's, Rediff in April had 9.66 million unique users, versus 13.6 million for Google in India and 14.6 million for Yahoo! That suggests that Rediff accounted for 25.5% of unique users, down from 34.1% at the end of 2005. ComScore wouldn't comment or confirm the data, which also showed Rediff trailing the two competitors in a host of other key metrics. A Rediff spokesman in Mumbai declined to comment ahead of the company's first-quarter earnings announcement in coming weeks, other than to say that comScore "changed their sampling methods in June 2006 and hence comparison between now and any period prior to June 2006 will be inaccurate."   The makeup of Rediff's earnings also raises questions. Some 53% of Rediff's '07 pretax profit of $7.04 million in the fiscal year ended March comes from interest on cash raised in a 2005 stock offering, an amount Rediff's chief executive, Ajit Balakrishnan, readily admits he has no immediate intention of spending. Not counting Rediff's $1.80 in cash, the company trades for 82 times earnings, compared with Google's current P/E of 29.   And 28% of revenues and just under a fifth of gross profit came from a publishing operation that is basically a newspaper, India Abroad, for Indian expats -- hardly a growth business that commands a premium valuation.     At Sify, some 58% of revenues comes from network services for business, 34% from franchised cybercafes and broadband access, and 5% from Internet portals. But though revenues from business services grew 26% over the year, retail-Internet access slowed down. And the company added fewer and fewer cybercafes, just 86 in the fiscal fourth quarter, well below previous rates.   Also falling are cybercafe fees as the number of establishments in the country soars, thanks to a push by the government. In October, HughesNet Fusion, a unit of Hughes Communications, announced that, backed by Microsoft, it's committed to rolling out 5,000 broadband kiosks in rural India -- somewhat more than Sify's existing 3,638 cafes.   Rumors of a takeover of Rediff have been stoked by interest expressed by both Google and Yahoo! in making Indian acquisitions, and Gilford Securities believes other suitors may surface. Gilford's Thadhani concedes the stock "has never been inexpensive," but he thinks a takeover could come at a premium to his existing price target of $25.   Last week, the stock was already above that price, even though Rediff chief Balakrishnan took the edge off takeover talk when he said he plans an offering in India "at some stage." Hardly the attitude of a corporate boss eager to sell his company.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Follow-Up: A Fertile Opportunity
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   While cautious traders might choose to take profits on a portion of their holdings, industry trends and Potash's dominant market share suggest that the stock has further to run. Indeed, it could climbanother 25% to 30% in the coming year.   First, the global demand for food crops -- and fertilizer, in turn -- shows no signs of abating, pushing potash prices up around the globe. Potash Corp. also produces nitrogen and phosphorus soil nutrients, but potash -- essentiallypotassium compounds left behind as sea water evaporates -- boasts the best margins.   Rising demand for biofuels is an added boon, as farmers lured by record grain prices strive to wring more from their soil. About a quarter of the growth in demand now comes from biofuels, which recently led CEO Bill Doyle to forecast "multiple years of good prices."   This is good news for all fertilizer companies, but especially Potash, which not only is the world's largest potash producer, but controls 75% of the industry's excess capacity. While rivals are stretched, Potash easily could fire up idle mines to satisfy growing demand.   At about 80, the company's shares sell near 27 times 2007 earnings. Sure, fertilizer no longer is a novel investment idea, but skepticism lingers, even after some sell-side analysts raised their targets to catch up to the stock. The company is expected to earn $2.97 a share in 2007 and $3.47 in 2008, up from $1.95 last year.   The potash rush isn't lost on global mining behemoths like BHP Billiton (BHP) and Rio Tinto (RTP), and speculation has increased that they're looking to expand their presence. While skeptics fret about tougher competition, the segment's formidable entry barriers -- it takes billions of dollars and five to 10 years to bring a new potash mine into production -- improve the odds that big miners will acquire existing producers to enter the space. Given Potash's upwardly mobile stock, any deal likely would carry a rich price tag.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China's Alibaba Hires Rothschild For Listing Plan - Paper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--China's biggest e-commerce company, Alibaba.com Corp., has appointed investment bank Rothschild to advise it on a stock market listing expected to raise at least $1 billion, The Daily Telegraph reported Saturday without citing sources.   Chairman Jack Ma is understood to have appointed Rothschild as the firm's financial adviser ahead of an anticipated flotation later this year, the newspaper said.   The move could lead to a huge windfall for Ma and for Yahoo! Inc. (YHOO), which holds a 40% stake in Alibaba, according to the Telegraph.   Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have been enlisted to underwrite the Alibaba share sale, which at this stage will involve only the company's business-to-business unit, the report said.   The flotation is likely to be the biggest-ever IPO by a Chinese Internet company and could value Alibaba's business arm at as much as $4 billion, it added.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 10:30 ET (14:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Tech Trader: Betting On The Xbox's Repairman
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   One of the current mysteries in the tech sector is the real story behind the problems afflicting Microsoft's Xbox 360 video-game consoles. As you no doubt know by now, Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) earlier this month announced that it was going to take a charge of more than $1 billion to cover costs related to an unusually large number of Xboxes with the dreaded (cue scary organ music) "three flashing red lights" hardware failure.   Microsoft has politely taken the blame itself, rather than pointing fingers at its component makers or contract manufacturers. One thing not many people have been talking about, however, is that all of that repair work is going to make money for someone. Alexander Blanton, an analyst at Ingalls & Snyder who is a long-time follower of the contract electronics-manufacturing sector, noted in a research report last week that Solectron (SLR) provides warranty repair services for the Xbox 360. The extension of the warranty on the box from one year to three years for the three-red-lights failure should give the company a fair share of the $1 billion Microsoft is going to spend to fix the problem.   I wish I could tell you to run out and buy Solectron based on the Xbox 360 repair work, but the stock isn't going to move on that news. That's because Solectron is in the process of being acquired by Flextronics (FLEX) for $3.6 billion in cash and stock. (Flextronics happens to manufacture the Xbox for Microsoft, along with Celestica (CLS)).   Blanton considers the Xbox work a modest positive for the combined companies, but his real point is more basic: He thinks you should take a stake in Flextronics. In particular, he thinks the Street is missing the positive impact Flextronics will see from buying Solectron. "We believe that not only is Flextronics undervalued in relation to its earnings potential during the next few years without Solectron, but also that investors are underestimating the additional value and potential earnings power Solectron brings to Flextronics," he writes in his research note.   As Blanton points out, the contract electronics-manufacturing business is huge, fragmented and highly competitive, in particular for high-volume goods like personal computers and cellphones. Where Solectron shines, he says, is in highly complicated goods; he says the company is the leading contract manufacturer for Cisco routers, for instance. (Cisco does almost none of its own manufacturing.) Blanton says the combined company "should be more diversified and more competitive than either company on its own."   Blanton notes that Flextronics is selling for just 13.6 times trailing 12-month earnings of 80 cents a share, and 10.9 times his estimate of $1 a share for the March 2008 fiscal year. "That's a paltry valuation for a company that expects to grow sales at least 10%-15% a year and EPS at an even faster rate," he writes.   Blanton sees Flextronics earning $1.20 per share in the March 2009 fiscal year, and $1.35 in fiscal 2010, not counting the pending acquisition of Solectron. But as Blanton notes, the company has said it expects to see $200 million in after-tax synergies from the Solectron deal within 24 months -- and he says it should be accretive to earnings in the first quarter after it closes. Blanton assumes the company will get half of the expected synergies in fiscal 2009; the result is his estimate jumps to $1.27 a share. For 2010, his estimate jumps to $1.72 a share, on the assumption that the company realizes the expected synergies.   I know that this sector has posed challenges for investors in recent years; and with its diverse exposure to the electronics-equipment business, Flextronics would likely get hurt in an economic downturn. But the stock is attractively priced. If you believe there is growth left in the tech business -- and that outsourcing manufacturing is the best option -- then you might want to stash away a few shares.     Let's go back for a second to the video-game business, in honor of last week's E3 gaming conclave in Los Angeles.   The current generation of video-game hardware -- the seventh generation, dating back to the Magnavox Odyssey in 1972 -- has almost certainly not turned out the way most people thought. At this point, we've got one console that keeps breaking (the Xbox 360), one that seems dramatically overpriced, even after a recent price cut (the Sony Playstation 3), and one that you can't ever find on the shelf because of its incredible popularity (the Nintendo Wii); it is likely to remain in short supply right through Christmas.   Last week's new, smaller E3 provided some pretty obvious indications that Nintendo has opened some eyes on the opportunities beyond hard-core gamers. Nintendo itself showed a balance board to be used in something called Wii Fit. (I could use that, I think.) Microsoft showed a new controller with large buttons, to make certain games easier to play. Sony . . . did I mention they cut prices?   Forrester Research last week issued a report on how the current generation of consoles will unfold between now and 2012, and theorized that this cycle will be more evenly divided among the competition than in previous rounds; in 2012, Forrester sees Xbox 360 with 33% of the market, the Wii with 30% and PS3 with 24%.   But they also provide a "wild-card scenario," in which Nintendo surges to the top of the heap. I'm a believer. We've had a Wii in our house since February, and it remains hugely popular with all three of my kids, who range from first grade to ninth grade. My six-year-old daughter beat the pants off me in the Wii Sports bowling game the other day. Purists will note it has a much less powerful processor than its rivals; it is about the same speed as the Playstation 2. But games ultimately aren't about how many polygons you can draw, or how lifelike surfaces look. Games are ultimately about fun. And the Wii, with its cool, innovative wireless controller, and easy-to-use games, is pure fun.     Litigation Watch: In a little-noticed ruling in June, a federal-court judge found that Japanese-owned wireless-networking-hardware maker Buffalo Technology was in violation of some Wi-Fi patents held by an Australian scientific agency called CSIRO, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. As my friend Gerard Hallaren of research-boutique JRPG.com points out, Buffalo was enjoined from selling infringing wireless hardware until it licenses the CSIRO patents. CSIRO had viewed the Buffalo litigation as a test case; it has litigation pending against larger tech companies, including Intel (INTC), Microsoft, Dell (DELL), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Netgear (NTGR), Nintendo (NTDOY) and Marvell (MRVL), among others.   Effectively, CSIRO contends anyone using the 802.11a or 802.11g standards in hardware is violating its patents. If the Buffalo cases holds up, the world will face the prospect of paying the Australian agency a tax on every Wi-Fi router and chipset -- which would generate enough cash to buy a whole lot of vegemite sandwiches.   ---   e-mail: eric.savitz@barrons.com.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Cleaning Up -2-
Story: Water purification and desalination have represented the holy grail of clean tech since before the term existed, but they remain elusive, primarily due to cost. Analysts at Lux Research project a $3 billion market opportunity in clean water, but the area has attracted only $154 million in venture-capital funding since 1995.   One company is taking a different tack toward providing fresh water. PICO Holdings (PICO), which is essentially an asset play, has been acquiring water rights throughout the West with plans to redistribute fresh water to areas where it's in short supply. The company has bought partial water rights to a massive aquifer (underground lake) in Nevada and is building a pipeline to a planned housing development in Reno. Analysts at Merriman Curhan aren't concerned about Pico's volatile earnings and revenues because it's an asset play.   Merriman Curhan sees the shares, at 43.47 last week, headed to 58.   Windmill farms might be the most ubiquitous symbol of alternative energy. Yet wind probably isn't the ultimate solution to our energy needs unless it meets sizable reliability, power storage and distribution challenges. Even environmentalists are tilting at them, arguing that they kill birds and make eyesores of our landscapes.   Another knock on wind energy has been the availability of windmills, or wind turbines. Composite Technology (CPTC.OB) hopes to help solve that problem. Its wholly-owned subsidiary, DeWind, is expected to release a new turbine later this year that should challenge General Electric and help address a significant global backlog. The shortfall in supply, Tanous explains, has occurred because GE, a major producer of turbines, owns much of the intellectual property and has made it difficult for others to compete without paying licensing fees.   But Irvine,Calif.-based Composite has developed its own technology, allowing it to cut into pent-up demand and earn high-profit margins. Merriman Curhan's Jesse Herrick, who just recently initiated coverage of the tiny company with a Buy, thinks the turbine breakthrough can propel fiscal '06 revenues of about $10 million to as high as $87 million by 2008.   With shares trading at only a buck or so, this nascent wind-play carries significant risk, but the company has another interesting aspect: carbon-fiber transmission lines for power companies. Herrick thinks this unit has potential upside as well and has a target of 2.50 for the stock.     To be sure, building a clean-technology industry that makes meaningful improvements in the global environment is a long-term project with many possible obstacles. Changes in the price of oil, for instance, will have a big effect on the marketplace. Products like hybrid cars or other transportation-related items will lose appeal if oil drops back into the $40-a-barrel area, even if the government mandates lower emissions.   And most solid clean-tech stocks are pretty rich. The frothiness seen in the current solar market can be expected to show up in other subsectors over time. Already, there have been questions about whether some fuel-cell makers can ever make a profit given their cost structures.   In some sense, bubble markets are a rite of passage for any new growth technology -- a validation of sorts. Certainly, the Internet has found its feet after a brutal few years. Is clean tech subject to the same fits and starts?   "Yes, but the difference is that we are not building sock puppets. Ultimately, investing in the Internet was right. It just took longer than expected," venture capitalist Dolezalek says. "These are real companies, building real revenues with real products." And growth investors have to live with real risk.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Police: 11 Tesco Supermarkets Closed On Security Alert -2-
Story: "Police are investigating a series of incidents in a number of locations across the country involving Tesco stores," a Hertfordshire police spokeswoman said on condition of anonymity in line with force police. "These stores have been temporarily closed as a precaution for public safety."   Tesco said the police had responded to a number of incidents.   "Police are investigating and so we are unable to comment further," she said on condition of anonymity in line with company policy. "As always, at all times customer welfare is our priority."   Police said the closures affected stores in London, other locations in England, and Scotland and Wales.   A spokesman for South Wales police said the Tesco store at Riverside, Port Talbot, had been closed since Saturday afternoon and said officers would remain at the store for as long as necessary.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 14:35 ET (18:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Up & Down Wall Street: Money Talks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   He who pays the piper calls the tune.   How's that for original phrasing? But for all it may be a bit shopworn, that familiar old saw depicts with remarkable precision how politics works.   Take the idea of making private equity and hedge funds subject to a tax rate that bears some relation to the mean tax bite inflicted on ordinary toilers doing an honest day's labor. On a lot of their enormous profits, the hedgies and the private-equity types pay 15%, instead of the up to 35% on the pittance earned by the sweat of our brow that we hapless lugs are liable for.   One would think such a proposal would be a no-brainer for Democrats like New York's senior senator, Charles Schumer, who are eternally posturing as friends of the working man and mouthing off about skimming some of the ill-gotten gains of the rich to enhance the common weal.   Ah, but no. Mr. Schumer, who's never at a loss for words, especially when there's a TV camera in sight, seems uncharacteristically constrained in his reaction to this latest wrinkle in the unceasing effort to separate the affluent from their proudest possession -- their money. Mr. Schumer suggests the need for careful weighing of the pros and cons of the proposal, a meditative approach that's quite alien to his usual assertive mode, and other liberal fire-eaters in the Congress apparently have experienced a similar conversion to the novel notion of think-before-you-shout.   A cynic might credit this onslaught of calm rationality to the fact that hedge funds and private-equity operators are big-buck contributors to the campaign kitties of Democrats. And a cynic would be absolutely right. But we want to reassure their various constituencies, those equivocating senators and congressmen are not opposed to soaking the rich; they are opposed only to soaking the rich who are enlightened enough to share the wealth with them.   The tender concern for the financial sensibilities of the worthies who run hedge funds and private-equity outfits is not restricted, in case you were worried it was, by petty partisanship. The Republicans, by and large, are arrayed against increasing taxes as a matter of principle and especially, as a matter of principal, against boosting the taxes of such generous donors to their campaigns as the hedge-fund and private-equity chieftains. An exception, we should note, is Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa, but then he probably grew up on a farm and so wouldn't know a CDO from a CMO and lacks the unique insight afforded those brave hearts who've engaged in tranche warfare.   Point man for the Republicans on this crucial issue seems to be John Snow, the former secretary of the Treasury. A brilliant choice, we say, for no one is better suited for that role than Mr. Snow, who parlayed an undistinguished career at the Treasury into a quite handsomely remunerative job as chairman of the insatiable private-equity octopus Cerberus Capital Management.   And Mr. Snow is proving just the fellow to eloquently delineate the horrors that will ensue to the free-enterprise system, the economy and the nation's well-being if, to cite one horrifying example, the top 25 hedge-fund managers were able to take home in any given year an average of only some $250 million. The very prospect of such extreme deprivation and cruel diminishment of incentive is enough to make widows and orphans weep, even those too impoverished by rash investments to own anything with which to wipe their tears.     Money talks in Wall Street, of course, and if possible, even more loudly than in Washington. But that's hardly surprising, since the bottom line on success or failure for participants in the market is simply how much money they make or lose. None of that pseudo-altruism, bettering-the-lot-of-mankind stuff that makes politics such an entertaining and enduring study in hypocrisy.   These days, moreover, money flows through the Street in an endless torrent, seeking employment in anything designed to whet the appetite of investors, from mammoth leveraged buyouts to billion-dollar buybacks by anxious companies of their own stock. This almost unimaginably bountiful fount of cash and credit, the blessed legacy of Mr. Greenspan's long reign at the Fed, is dispensed by unfailingly generous banks and their less traditional counterparts, eager for the absurdly fat fees, a piece of the action, or both.   And there's seemingly an inexhaustible supply of money champing at the bit to stampede into stocks at the drop of even the flimsiest excuse. Last Thursday bore dramatic witness to just how breathtakingly explosive buying power can be when it comes bursting in from the sidelines, where, incidentally, it had hastily sought refuges just a few days before from one of those selling squalls that have punctuated this year's spanking bullish run.   The Dow spurted 283.86 points to a new  high within spitting distance of 14,000, its biggest gain since October '02, when it was just beginning to find its legs after the bear market that opened this century. For their part, the S&P 500 and Russell 2000 also soared to new historic peaks, and even the still-lame Nasdaq touched its highest levels in six years (but, before you get too excited, a couple of thousand-plus points from its best-ever close some seven years ago).   What set off the blazing rise supposedly were some not-so-bad reports by a few retail chains, notably Wal-Mart, of how their sales fared in June, presumably evidence that reports the consumer is ready for intensive care are greatly exaggerated. That explanation, we respectfully submit, is pure, unadulterated balderdash.   The showing of most retail chains was mediocre at best, and even Wal-Mart, on second glance, benefited most conspicuously from higher food prices than any exceptional pick-up in its regular business. And along comes Friday and with it the Commerce Department's disclosure that retail sales last month plummeted 0.9% to a two-year low (even ex autos, the drop was a dispiriting 0.4%).   In truth, fear was the big trigger for Thursday's blistering rally -- fear, once the market started up in earnest, of being left behind, and fear, by the overly crowded short-interest position, of unpleasant losses swiftly blossoming into disastrous ones. In both cases, the hedge funds, a flighty bunch if ever there was one, acted as significant catalysts.   As to that other old reliable explanation dragged out whenever the need arises -- big noise on the takeover front, which last week was supplied by Rio Tinto handily outbidding Alcoa for Alcan -- it served, as do so many mergers and acquisitions, more as rationale than reason for buying.   Manias, by definition, are marked by a compulsion to buy, and that's been the story of this market for quite a spell now. There are likely other elements at work that are not much articulated but, we suspect, help feed the passion for equities. The weakness of the dollar, for one; rightly or otherwise, stocks are commonly viewed as a buffer against a devaluating currency.   We can't say when the irrepressible urge of investors to buy will dissipate, whether it'll happen overnight or over time or what precisely will cause it to do so. All we can say confidently is that it'll happen, and we're not talking about the hereafter.     Among the dictates of our job is to rummage through a vast miscellany of investment and economic commentary from brokerage firms, investment banks, all manner of advisory outfits and other dubious sources. Much of the material is nicely packaged (or not) rubbish, which no doubt comes as a big shock to you. There are, however, among the fluff and dross inevitably some worthwhile pieces, in which happy category we include a good slice of the stuff churned out by Dresdner Kleinwort.   We're particularly taken by the scribblings of Albert Edwards and Ian Hardwood, which we see with some frequency, but we think the level of analysis and liveliness of expression overall deserves a nod. Sometimes a stray observation or fact is particularly intriguing. Ian points out, for example, in a discussion the growing likelihood of a "generalized mortgage credit crunch" in the U.S., that rising mortgage applications, which more than one observer has seized upon as sign of a bottom in housing, instead might be symptomatic of a "growing propensity to make multiple applications" because of the difficulty of getting a mortgage.   And in his most recent commentary, Albert Edwards observes that, "given the still gargantuan borrowing requirement of the U.S. household sector needed to finance elevated levels of spending, a loss of confidence could easily trigger a consumer collapse."   He goes on, in a cheerfully mordant tone, that should the U.S. consumer "eventually slump, the market will be stunned. Equities would join the wake, with sky-high margins (especially in the financial sector), cyclically ripe for retrenchment."   Finally, he sighs, if the unthinkable happens and the "profits cycle turns, who will be left to buy the equity market? Certainly not the corporate sector. Excessive peak-of-cycle and LBO-levitated valuations will sink back into the Ice Age abyss and talk will return once again to deflation."   We can only infer that Albert did not participate whole-heartedly in last week's stock-market surge.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Warner Music In Talks With Private Equity Over EMI -Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Warner Music Group Corp. (WMG) is in talks with more than one private equity firm about a potential break-up bid for EMI Group PLC (EMI.LN) ahead of next Thursday's put-up or shut-up deadline, The Daily Telegraph in London reported Saturday without citing sources.   Private equity firm Terra Firma has given EMI shareholders an extra week to accept its GBP2.4 billion bid pitched at 265p a share.   If Warner does not launch a counterbid, it is expected to seek to buy EMI recorded music from Terra Firma at a later date, the Telegraph said.   Warner declined to comment to the newspaper. Headline: Barron's(7/16) Cleaning Up
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   It's that rare opportunity to save humanity and make a killing.   The mere possibility has Silicon Valley's venture capitalists tripping over each other to offer cash to start-ups focused on Clean Technology, a fuzzy business category that now encompasses just about anything that might help stave off global warming and aid the environment: solar and wind-generated energy sources, air and water pollution-control devices, and alternative fuels made from just about any non-hydrocarbon-based item all qualify. Even electric sports cars seem to fit the bill.   Venture capitalists plunked down better than $1.5 billion in funding for clean tech in 2006, bringing the total to $4.2 billion since 2000, according to the National Venture Capital Association.
