These strong inflows have helped launch 1,500 start-ups worldwide.   "These companies are popping up like weeds, just like dot-coms, but hopefully with better rates of success," says Vinod Khosla, the well-respected venture capitalist who founded Khosla Ventures and is an affiliated partner at Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield and Byers.   More than 50 of these one-time weeds already have progressed beyond private-equity funded start-ups and entered the public markets in the past two years or so, which begs the question of how well they'll fare longer-term. Will the attrition rate among clean-tech companies be as high as it was for Internet companies (not to mention their shareholders)?   Clean tech no doubt will suffer from some of the same ills as the Internet: Already, solar stocks are frothy, ethanol shares have soared only to plunge as corn prices rose, and some fuel-cell companies seem to have borrowed their business plans from long-departed Web enterprises. But the sector also appears to be a fertile source of profitable growth investments for the next decade or more. There's already a decent selection of stocks to buy in this area, with substantial upside.   In part, this is because governments worldwide are expected to pass tougher environmental laws aimed at saving the planet, by forcing industry and utilities to do less harm. Global accords like the Kyoto Protocol, which limits carbon-dioxide emissions and promotes trading of emission rights, are gaining. Just last week in the U.S., which didn't agree to the protocol, the Senate introduced a measure that would mandate a "cap and trade" system that  limits total emissions and then allows carbon-dioxide producers to trade emission credits.   "The likely trajectory of legislation on global warming is creating a great investment opportunity," says Khosla.   Added impetus comes from the U.S.' dangerous dependence on foreign oil.   "There is a natural alliance here between the tree-huggers and the hawks, even if they don't agree on the reasons," says R. James Woolsey, director of the Central Intelligence Agency in the Clinton administration who works for consultants Booz Allen Hamilton.   "With about two-thirds of the world's oil supply situated in the tumultuous Middle East, we need to do to oil what electricity and refrigeration did to salt at the turn of the 19th century," says Woolsey. Salt still mattered after new means of preserving food were discovered, but it was no longer a strategic commodity that triggered wars.     In February, the California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund, pledged to commit $400 million to private-equity investments in clean tech managed by Pacific Corporate Group of La Jolla, Calif.   California's move provided an added measure of validation to the category, which increasingly is moving into the public markets. Thirty clean-tech outfits went public in 2006, raising about $4.4 billion, following the 19 that generated roughly $1.7 billion in 2005. The American Stock Exchange now has a Cleantech Index (CTIUS) and there's a PowerShares' WilderHill Clean Energy Portfolio exchange-traded fund (PBW), one of a number of vehicles devoted to the group. (Barron's parent, Dow Jones, announced last week that it was launching a new Clean Tech news service for investors.)   Investors will have to negotiate a market that's likely to resemble biotech more than the Internet or information tech, says VantagePoint Venture Partners' Stephan Dolezalek, whose firm has invested in 11 companies to the tune of about $140 million since 2001 and plans to invest another $100 million or so a year.   As in biotech, venture capitalists are more likely to exit their investments in clean tech via buyouts rather than IPOs. In part this is because clean tech faces more uncertainties -- owing to its reliance on changing government policies and subsidies, an evolving customer base and huge capital needs -- than information-technology firms that had more defined sets of customers.   They will also compete against huge multinationals, which are likely to be active acquirers both for defensive purposes and as ways to enter new areas, Dolezalek says.   Instead of Big Pharma, it will be oil, chemical, agricultural, and energy-utility behemoths, among them companies like General Electric, BP, Dow Chemical, ConAgra, Monsanto that will be on the prowl for these companies. The start-ups, like fledgling biotech companies, will get brand recognition, distribution, big sales forces and manufacturing help while the acquirers will receive needed growth and knowledge.   It's too early to invest on this basis, but some big companies may also be long-term beneficiaries of clean tech. What would happen to General Motors' shares if the auto maker  produced a car that got 100 miles to the gallon or didn't use fossil fuels at all? The same kind of breakthroughs could occur at GE (wind and lighting) or Archer Daniels Midland (ethanol).   That's not to say we shouldn't expect some new household names to emerge. While it produced fewer than those spawned in the computer revolution, biotech still gave us giants like Amgen and Genentech. If clean tech ever produces a comparable name, it's likely to come from the broad and diverse energy sector that's captured more than half of all clean-tech venture money.     Whether turning cow chips and corn into biofuels or harnessing the wind and sun, these alternatives to fossil fuels are going to garner more attention as the science improves, public policy shifts and storage capability grows. It is also where traditional Silicon Valley semiconductor technology intersects with new frontiers, such as solar cells and energy storage like batteries.   One of the early success stories and highfliers is SunPower (SPWR), a majority-owned spin-off of Cypress Semiconductor (CY). Nothing fancy here, SunPower is a well-managed maker and seller of high-efficiency silicon solar cells and panels based on today's technology. "It's the premier solar photovoltaic company," says Brion Tanous, a next-generation energy analyst with Merriman Curhan Ford in San Francisco. (Thermal solar, which heated water, was considered the first generation of solar where photovoltaic is the next generation that turns light into electricity).   The company has a market-leading position in Spain, one of the world's biggest promoters of alternative energy, a 2.2-megawatt solar-power plant in Korea and is starting on the largest solar installation in the U.S. The company racked up about $237 million in sales last year, with profits of $36 million, or 51 cents a share.   Supporting a market value in excess of $5 billion, the shares hit their 52-week high last week at 69.80, or a pricey 36 times 2008 earnings. Some insist it's worth it for high-quality growth. Merriman Curhan's target is 75. Says one angel investor: "It's rich, but it's kind of like buying Microsoft in the early '90s. It will just stay rich."   Another alternative start-up is New Hampshire-based Environmental Power Corp. (EPG),  a big bet on the institution of emissions caps and the trading of pollution credits in the U.S. The company's technology cuts the natural release of animal-produced methane, a carbon-based gas that contributes to the Greenhouse Effect. Under a trading system, Environmental Power would get valuable credits for its efforts which could translate into a new revenue stream beyond its main business of turning methane into biofuel. Analyst Tanous estimates the credits could be worth as much as $4.6 million, or 33 cents a share, by 2009.   Major investors have eyed the shares of this unprofitable company, but a market value of $84 million doesn't provide them enough liquidity. Shares were trading around 8 last week, below their 9.34 52-week high. "Small-cap investors are buying this stock," Tanous says. "And I think it has a long way to run." He has a target of 16, or 23 if the value of carbon credits is twice what's expected.     Making power plants run more efficiently at lower costs is a big-step toward cleaning the air, which is where Fuel Tech (FTEK) comes in. It is a $75 million-in-revenue company that installs air-pollution controls that improve the performance of combustion furnaces.   The company has borrowed its business model from shavers and blades: The system is cheap but the recurring revenues from supplying the chemicals to keep it going produce high margins. It has a chemical injection system for oil- and coal-fuel plants that eliminates the layers of petrified slag that build up on the inside surfaces of the furnaces. Now, the slag that once had to be broken up with explosives, is turned to ash workers can simply sweep out of the furnace.   Coming off all-time highs in June, the shares could catch a second wind after the company's recent announcement that it's partnering with a Japanese company to sell its systems in China. Plus, the expected adoption of a carbon-credit system in the U.S. should generate more U.S. demand.   The stock is trading at 46 times Tanous' 2008 earnings estimate of 71 cents a share. But he thinks 2008 revenue can grow 30%. "You could even argue that it's not that expensive now," says Tanous, who sees it climbing 25%, to 41.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Dubai May Derail OMX-Nasdaq Merger With Rival Bid -Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The owner of the Dubai stock exchange is poised to derail the proposed $3.7 billion merger between OMX AB (OMX.SK) and Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. (NDAQ) by tabling a rival bid, The Daily Telegraph reported Saturday without citing sources.   The Dubai International Financial Centre, which owns the Dubai International Financial Exchange, is believed to have funding in place to bid up to SEK250 per OMX share, some 20% higher than Nasdaq's existing SEK208.1-a-share bid, the report said.   According to the Telegraph, UBS and Goldman Sachs are understood to have been asked to be on standby to launch a bid for OMX on behalf of the DIFC as early as next week.   The DIFC is understood to have been buying OMX shares in the open market in recent days, amassing a stake in the region of 4.5%, just below the 5% level at which a buyer must disclose ownership under Swedish stock exchange rules, the newspaper added.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 10:36 ET (14:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: China Bans Food Products From Tyson, Other US Cos
Story: (Adds details on import suspensions, comments from Chinese product safety official)   BEIJING (AP)--China has suspended imports from Tyson Foods Inc. (TSN) and several other U.S. meat processors - the latest indication the government may be retaliating as its products are turned back from overseas because of safety concerns.   Frozen poultry products from Tyson, the world's largest meat processor, were found to be contaminated with salmonella, China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine said on its Web site late Friday.   Other imports barred by China include frozen chicken feet from Sanderson Farms, Inc. (SAFM), tainted with residue of an anti-parasite drug, as well as frozen pork ribs from Cargill Meat Solutions Corp. that contained a leanness-enhancing feed additive, the AQSIQ said.   A Cargill spokesman denied the agency's claims. Tyson and Sanderson Farms officials were not immediately available for comment.   China's food and drug safety has come under scrutiny in recent months following North American dog and cat deaths blamed on tainted Chinese pet food ingredients.   Worries at home and around the world have heightened as a growing number of Chinese products have been found tainted with dangerous levels of toxins and chemicals.   Beijing has taken steps in recent days to improve product safety. It executed the former head of its drug regulation agency for taking bribes, and banned toothpaste makers from using a chemical found in antifreeze.   China's government has thoroughly investigated each case of substandard products, the official Xinhua News Agency on Saturday quoted Li Yuanping, director of the AQSIQ's import and export bureau, as saying.   "All of them are exceptional cases," he said in the report, adding more than 99% of China's exports meet standards.   "There is no such thing as zero risk. In term of food safety, it's impossible for any country to make 100% of their foodstuff safe," he was quoted as saying. "China-made products should not be labeled as substandard just because of a few bad producers."   However, as China works on food safety, authorities have prominently announced rejected imports - an apparent bid to turn the tables on critics and show it is not the only country with food export safety problems.   Mark Klein, a spokesman for Minneapolis-based Cargill Inc., disputed the Chinese inspectors' findings and said the company hoped to resolve the issue by working with U.S. and Chinese officials.   "We're proud of our products and our processes, and we'll be delighted to talk about them with all concerned," he said.   Cargill is the parent company of Wichita, Kansas-based Cargill Meat Solutions Corp., which as of 2005 was the ninth leading pork producer in the U.S., according to the National Pork Producers Council.   Cargill had 45 days to correct the problem, the AQSIQ said, as did Kansas City, Missouri-based Van Luin Foods USA, Inc., whose imports of frozen pig ears were also found to contain the leanness-enhancing feed additive ractopamine.   The other companies' imports were suspended, although the AQSIQ did not say for how long.   It was unclear whether the latest import bans covered only the products in question, or all of the companies' imports.   An AQSIQ duty officer said Saturday said he did not know details.   Also suspended from import were products from two Atlanta-based companies: frozen chicken feet tainted with salmonella from Intervision Foods, and frozen pork tainted with ractopamine from AJC International, Inc.   Phones at both companies rang unanswered late Friday.   Messages seeking comment were left with two spokesmen     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 05:42 ET (09:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Speaking Of Dividends: Cummins Keeps Rolling
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   The slowdown in the heavy-duty truck industry is no roadblock for Cummins. The 88-year-old Columbus, Ind., company, long the world's No. 1 manufacturer of big diesel engines, boasts three consecutive years of record financial results.   Tuesday, Cummins (ticker: CMI) revved up its quarterly common dividend 39%, to 25 cents a share. The payout had been stalled at 15 cents from late 1999 until last July, when directors upped it to 18 cents. The new dividend is payable Aug. 31 to investors of record Aug. 17, and the stock goes ex-dividend Aug. 15. Cummins, whose engines also go into smaller trucks, buses, and mining and construction equipment, started paying dividends in 1948.   Chief Executive Tim Solso said the company's "strong financial performance has resulted in significant positive cash flow, which has allowed us to strengthen our balance sheet and invest in profitable growth." (Last year, profits climbed 30%, to $7.11 a share, on a 15% jump in sales to $11.4 billion.) At the same time, he added, "we understand the need to reward our shareholders' confidence... by returning value on their investment through increased share price, growing dividends and repurchasing stock."   From 2003 through 2006, Cummins produced an average annual total return (share-price appreciation, plus dividends) of approximately 46%-more than triple the S&P 500's and better than double its peer group's.   Traded on the Big Board, the shares have more than doubled over the past year and were split 2-for-1 in April. They set a 52-week high Monday of 120.18, after Bear Stearns analyst Peter Nesvold upgraded the stock to Outperform from Peer Perform, saying the new federal emissions rules for heavy-duty trucks, slated to take effect in 2010, would hurt Cummins' competitors over the coming years, but that Cummins is set to benefit from the changes. Cummins is also investing in diesels for cars and light trucks, which it believes will comprise 25% of the U.S. market in eight to 10 years.   Nesvold sees the stock at 130 by the end of 2008.   With the global economy growing at a faster clip than here at home, U.S. companies with operations abroad will benefit because of the weak dollar. As it happens, Cummins is the largest foreign investor in China's diesel-engine industry. It sold $1.2 billion worth of goods there in 2006 and expects to triple that number in three years.     The nation's largest drugstore chain, Walgreen (WAG) has paid dividends for 74 consecutive years and now has sweetened its payout for 32 years in a row. Walgreen boosted its quarterly Wednesday to 9.5 cents a share from 7.75 cents. Disbursement will take place Sept. 12 for holders of record Aug. 20. The ex-date is Aug. 16.   The shares change hands roughly a half-dozen points below their 52-week high of 51.60, set in September. Standard & Poor's earlier this month raised its investment rating on the stock to Strong Buy from Buy. The firm thinks "non-pharmacy sales will benefit from various measures to improve customer convenience at the company's stores and its exclusive merchandising. We see the acquisition of a health-clinic operator [Take Care Health Systems] and the rollout of 400-plus in-store health-care clinics in 2008 boosting traffic." Citing increased margin contributions from sales of generic drugs, S&P lifted its fiscal 2007 (ending August 31) per-share earnings estimate by three cents to $2.12 and its 12-month price target by $2 to 56. Walgreen said it's on target to surpass its goal of 7,000 stores in 2010.   CVS (CVS), Walgreen's closest competitor, was recently quoted at 36 and change and pays a quarterly dividend of six cents a share.     On July 1, Bank of New York completed its $16.5 billion takeover of Pittsburgh-based Mellon Financial. Tuesday, Bank of New York Mellon (BK) declared a quarterly common dividend of 24 cents a share. Yield: 2.10%. Each company had paid 22 cents prior to the merger.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Profile: Black Box With Heart
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   Talking With   John Montgomery   Founder and Chief Executive   Bridgeway Fund     While many on Wall Street single-mindedly worship Mammon, the same can't be said for the 24-member mutual-fund company Bridgeway Funds.   On a recent morning, its founder and CEO, John Montgomery, spent much of a weekly employee meeting talking about a holocaust survivor he'd met on a recent trip to Great Britain and her inspiring tale of how she and her mother were rescued from near-certain death in an Austrian concentration camp by the providential arrival of Alliedforces.   Each year, Bridgeway gives half of its net profits to charities, ranging from community groups and a Haitian medical clinic to genocide relief organizations around the world. Last year, the total came to $8 million, with individual employees (called "partners") being able to designate $20,000 gifts to charities they select.     Montgomery's philosophy of egalitarianism and antimaterialism extends to other aspects of Bridgeway, which currently manages $5.6 billion in assets. He limits his own annual compensation to seven times the level of his lowest-paid employee.   "Executive compensation is way out of whack in this country, so we have our own system to reduce any possible animosity in the firm," the lanky 52-year-old says during an interview at the company's headquarters in a bank building in Houston, near the Rice University campus.   "We tell job applicants that if they want to make millions right away, they should look elsewhere, but if they want to make a real difference in life, this is the place. Look, we make decent money here -- more than enough for our people to have a spiritually satisfying life." Likewise, investors appear to get a more than a fair shake from Bridgeway's mutual funds, which impose no loads or 12b-1 fees.   And Bridgeway employees have a strong reason for wanting the funds to succeed. The firm mandates that they invest in the funds, and doesn't allow them to invest elsewhere.   Management fees and other fund expenses are below industry averages. And the fees have a substantial performance component, ensuring that Bridgeway is rewarded for beating the market and punished for trailing it.   A mistake in how the firm calculated performance fees led to a 2004 regulatory settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under which the company agreed to pay $4.4 million in fees, plus interest, to investors in three of its funds. Yet that hasn't deterred fund-rater Morningstar from consistently giving Bridgeway high marks on stewardship, both before and after the affair.     Bridgeway is quick to close funds to new investors, forgoing additional profit when cash flows threaten to make the funds unwieldy. In addition, the company strives to hold down trading costs and keep its funds tax-efficient, even though some have annual portfolio turnover rates exceeding 100%.   Bridgeway is also one of the few fund groups to rely solely on computer models, rather than a phalanx of high-priced security analysts and managers, to pick stocks. "Ours is a pure quantitative approach that not only takes a lot of cost out of the process, but also much of the emotionalism that so often trips up individual and institutional investors alike," Montgomery says.   Bridgeway's black-box, or quantitative, approach seem to have worked since the company was launched in 1994. Since then, all 11 of its funds have beaten the indexes against which they're measured -- some spectacularly so.   For example, the multi-cap Bridgeway Aggressive Investors 1 Fund ($373 million in assets) has notched an average annual return of 20.74% since its inception in September 1994 through this year's second quarter, compared with average annual returns of 11.6% for the Standard & Poor's 500 index in the same span.   The Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company Fund ($140 million in assets) has produced average annual returns of 22.26% during the same period, around 5.5 percentage points better than its benchmark, Chicago's Center for Research in Securities Prices Index, which measures the performance of the smallest 10th of companies on the Big Board, Amex and Nasdaq.   The 10-year record of Aggressive Investors 1 (ticker: BRAGX) puts it second among 269 mid-cap growth funds tracked by Morningstar. Ultra-Small Company (BRUSX) finished third out of 231 small-cap growth funds in Morningstar's database.   Montgomery's path to a career in money management was anything but direct. He started out as a transportation engineer, after earning engineering degrees at Swarthmore College and graduate school at MIT. The vocation satisfied his do-gooder impulses. "Some studies have showed that grinding commutes and poor public transportation have almost as negative an impact on personal happiness as the strain of children taking care of a parent suffering from dementia," he observes.   His engineering work also accustomed him to applying statistics and advanced mathematics to such esoterica as optimizing bus schedules and predicting traffic flows. Montgomery insists that it wasn't that much of an intellectual leap to developing similar computer models to capture the behavior of another complex system  -- the stock market.     He began using models to invest for his own account in 1982 after inheriting a modest legacy upon the death of his father. That same year, he also enrolled in Harvard's MBA program to learn more about business and investing.   There, he claims to have had an epiphany in a finance class: In the main, investors -- especially bright Harvard MBA students -- don't consistently beat the market, because they're both too cocksure and too prone to emotional swings. They lack the iron discipline of rationality and careful diversification of risk that black-box investing can provide.   Yet, after realizing this, he didn't really consider quitting his day job at the Houston Metropolitan Transport System -- until the early 1990s, when his accountant, wowed by the trading profits showing up on Montgomery's stock returns, year after year, asked Montgomery to manage his own retirement account.   It took Montgomery until 1993 to incorporate, and another year to start his first funds, which he operated out of a tiny corner office in a strip mall across the street from the current Bridgeway offices.   Bridgeway initially proved a hard slog, attracting just $10 million in its first two years. Then, Mutual Funds magazine highlighted the lights-out performance of Ultra-Small Company, which returned 39.84% in 1995 and 29.74% in 1996. The article spurred some 10,000 requests for fund prospectuses, and money began pouring in.   To this day, to hold down expenses for existing shareholders, Bridgeway does little marketing. In line with its philosophy -- You found us; we didn't sell you -- Bridgeway gets new business mainly via word-of-mouth, unsolicited news articles like the one you are reading, and favorable mention in databases.   Institutions don't give Bridgeway much money. The exception: the socially conscious Calvert Fund family, for which the company subadvises on $1.6 billion of small- and large-cap funds.   If Bridgeway's quant philosophy isn't a complete conversation-stopper with pension funds and the like, it certainly is an inhibitor. As Montgomery observes with bemusement: "It's something of a mystery to me, given our record, why our technique is greeted with so much skepticism. Isn't what goes on inside the head of a fabled mutual-fund manager, like Fidelity's Peter Lynch, as much a black box as our models? At least if something were to happen to me, our models would just keep on cranking."     Bridgeway follows 3,500 stocks, ranging from behemoths like General Electric down to micro and ultra-small names.   All are ranked according to their price potential, employing a clutch of proprietary computer models looking at different characteristics. Portfolios are then cobbled together from the top finishers in different models to assure diversification in the stocks' attributes, sectors and risk characteristics.   The composition of the 16 different models that Bridgeway uses are, not surprisingly, closely guarded secrets. Montgomery doesn't want to be front-run or slip-streamed by nosy rivals. "All I can say is that our models have multiple variables and different factor weightings," he comments.   Some idea of the company's methodology can be gleaned, however, from factors that Bridgeway has tried unsuccessfully to model and back-test.   He avers, for example, that insider trading data is overrated in delineating the future direction of stocks. There's a perceptible "January effect" boosting small-cap stocks, but transaction costs limit the phenomenon's profit potential. And, he adds, noise in the data makes shifts in economic growth or Fed policy moves all but impossible to model.   Likewise, Bridgeway has never found much value in using moving averages to measure stock-price momentum. And merely culling picks from stocks with low price-to-earnings ratios doesn't work unless growth potential factors are spooned in.   Bridgeway's multi-cap, "go-anywhere" Aggressive Investors I Fund and its larger near-clone, the $651 million Bridgeway Aggressive Investors 2 (BRAIX), are run with stocks selected from six different models.   One is purely technical, measuring how stocks have acted in terms of price and volume changes.   Three other models are biased toward growth stocks trying to glean future trends from past growth in earnings, cash flow, book value and the like. Yet in one of the growth models, value looms important. "We call this one our 'growth at a reasonable price' model," says Montgomery.   Finally, two pure-value-stock models are employed.     He also talks excitedly about a new "contrarian" model that the firm is rolling out. It's designed to uncover stocks that have been unfairly beaten to a pulp.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Police: 11 Tesco Supermarkets Closed On Security Alert
Story: LONDON (AP)--U.K. police closed at least 11 Tesco PLC (TSCDY) supermarkets across the country Saturday because of a security alert, authorities said.   Police in Hertfordshire - where Tesco, the U.K.'s largest supermarket, has its headquarters - said no one had been hurt and that the move was a precaution. Police didn't immediately give further details.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 14:18 ET (18:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Follow-Up: Lighting Up The Construction Industry
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Many companies managed to beat analysts' profit estimates in the first quarter; McDermott International, the energy-services outfit, trounced consensus views, lighting a fire under the stock that should burn for a while.   Fueled by sizzling backlog growth and margin expansion at its J. Ray offshore-construction unit, McDermott (ticker: MDR) almost tripled profits from the year-earlier first period, surpassing estimates by 86%. It might be too much to expect the Houston company to duplicate such performance anytime soon, but continued growth in the backlog amid robust capital spending in the energy sector should drive double-digit annual earnings increases for the next couple of years.   Due in part to the first-quarter results, McDermott's stock has climbed 84% for the year, to a recent 89, and is up 56% since Barron's cited it as a compelling bet on energy ("Power Player in the Oil Patch," May 3).   The stock remains attractive, selling at 18.5 times analysts' estimate of $4.81 a share for next year. By contrast, the five major engineering and construction companies trade for 24 times, on average. Assigning a P/E of 21 to McDermott, one of the sector's few pure plays on energy, would put the stock at 101, up 13%.   "We believe that since the market has started valuing MDR as an E&C company, the P/E gap will continue to narrow," says Calyon Securities' Mark Urness.   The stock has stalled a bit since hitting its high of 91 on July 6, but strong second-quarter results could kick-start shares into the mid-90s, predicts Urness. Analysts expect McDermott to report 94 cents for the period ending this month, up from 71 cents a year ago. But bulls are betting on margins at J. Ray above the 13% some analysts' are expecting, lifting profits above views.   In all, McDermott may light up the engineering and construction sector for some time to come.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Follow-Up: Coach: It's All In The Bag
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Outright cheap back then, the stock is now fairly valued, given the company's still-strong growth outlook. Hence, the shares are likely to appreciate at a slower pace than the company's expected 20% annual earnings growth in the next few years as Coach matures, with some bumpy stretches along the way.   The rally came as Coach (ticker: COH), maker of immensely popular handbags and accessories, continued its record of hit new-product rollouts, brisk store openings, double-digit same-store sales gains and 30%-plus profit growth. Earnings in the fiscal year that ended June 30 are pegged at $1.68 a share, 10% higher than the estimate for the year back in July 2006. Profit is likely to top $2 a share in fiscal 2008.   Coach shares, valued a year ago at 19 times the company's forecast earnings for the next four quarters, now trade at 25 times forward earnings. The current valuation is almost precisely at the median price-earnings ratio for Coach over the past five years, a period when the stock has gone up sevenfold. Its P-E relative to that of the Standard & Poor's 500 is also right at its long-term average.   In other words, Coach shares now properly incorporate the company's impressive growth prospects. The company has an admirable multichannel distribution strategy, with some 250 stand-alone Coach stores, a department-store presence and 90 factory-outlet locations.   Happily for Coach, women are buying more handbags (an average of four last year industrywide, versus two in 2000). Coach has fed this demand by frequently refreshing its product line and intensely researching customer preferences.   Chairman Lew Frankfort canceled the back half of a planned sale of 500,000 shares in mid-May, with the stock near 46. Frankfort, a 25-year Coach veteran who has sold large quantities of the stock in recent years, halted sale programs twice before when he believed the stock was undervalued.   The stock, up from 28 a year ago to about 49, certainly could use a rest or pullback; it has experienced declines of 17% to 32% in the spring and summer of the past two calendar years. If this happens, investors should welcome it as an attractive markdown on prime merchandise.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Court Rules German Train Drivers Are Allowed To Strike
Story: BERLIN (AP)--German national railway train drivers are allowed to strike as part of demands for higher wages, a labor court ruled Saturday, repealing an injunction imposed last week.   The GDL union, representing many drivers for Deutsche Bahn AG, is seeking wage increases of up to 31% for some of its members.   Last week, Deutsche Bahn sought a court injunction to prevent walkouts by the drivers, after they staged two several-hour strikes that brought parts of the network to a standstill. But a labor court in Mainz repealed that, paving the way for the possibility of new strikes.   Deutsche Bahn is offering GDL the same deal it reached with two other unions. That agreement, reached on Monday, foresees a 4.5% pay rise Jan. 1 and one-time payments of  EUR600 to cover the second half of this year.   Both sides met for talks Friday, but failed to reach an agreement. They are scheduled to meet again on Thursday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 12:07 ET (16:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Asian Trader: Indonesian Market Is Hot, And Getting Hotter
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Assif Shameen   July marks the 10th anniversary of the start of Asia's financial crisis, when currencies and stock markets plunged and investors fled.   Few countries were harder hit than Indonesia, which has Southeast Asia's largest economy. Protestors flooded the streets, ultimately forcing out the dictator Suharto and paving the way for free elections and a more open economy with increased privatization and deregulation. Today, Indonesia looks like a 1990s-era Asian tiger: The Jakarta Composite Index is up 33% this year, and 55% over 12 months -- and has surged nearly tenfold from its mid-1998 Asian-crisis low point.   "Strong, pro-growth policies [are] in place, and president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono has a good record of delivering on his promises," says Ray Jovanovich, chief investment officer at Credit Agricole Asset Management, Hong Kong. Foreign direct investment is rising, and rich Indonesians who took their money overseas are returning to find value back home.   The Indonesian economy grew 5.5% last year, and is projected to expand 6.2% this year and 6.5% in 2008. "Indonesia hasn't grown this fast in the decade since the crisis," says economist Bill Belchere of Macquarie Bank.   As inflation has steadily fallen, the central bank has cut interest rates 13 times over the past 18 months, from 12% to 8.25%, and economists expect rates to fall to 8% this year and 7.5% by the end of 2008.   Still, "Indonesia is far from cheap and much of the interest-rate decline is priced in," says Citigroup analyst David Fergusson. ABN Amro's Dominique Dwor-Frecaut is more cautious. "The market is underestimating growing inflation risks and macro-economic stability is still fragile," she warns.   But bulls see plenty of upside. "Indonesia is in an early cycle of sustained economic expansion," says Mark Matthews, regional strategist for Merrill Lynch in Singapore. "Though Indonesia's structural reform story isn't as strong as new markets like Pakistan and Vietnam, it truly belongs in the large, fast-growing emerging-markets BRIC [Brazil, Russia, India, China] group."   Corporate earnings look set to grow 23% this year and over 20% next year, which would be the strongest showing in Asia. Stocks are trading just above 18 times this year's profits, versus an average 50 times for China's A-shares market.   Citigroup recently raised its 12-month target for the JCI Index to 2,600 -- 16% above its current reading. At that level, the Jakarta market would still be selling at 16.8 times next year's earnings.   Merrill's Matthews sees several attractive growth sectors: infrastructure, consumer, plantations and mineral resources. Jakarta has approved $150 billion worth of mainly private-sector-financed infrastructure projects by 2010, including ports, roads, bridges and power plants. Big winners in the boom are cement makers like Indocement (ticker: INTP.Indonesia) and Semen Grasik (SMGR.ID), but some analysts say cement stocks have run ahead of themselves.   Another hot sector is commodities. As a big exporter of resources like coal, nickel, gold, copper, rubber, tin and gas, Indonesia is benefiting from the boom in China and India. Nickel producer Inco (INCO.ID) and coal producer Bumi Resources (BUMI.ID) have had huge rallies over the past year. Indonesia, the world's biggest crude palm-oil producer, is building huge capacity for palm-based biodiesel.   Citigroup has a Buy on Astra Agro Lestari (AALI.ID), a pure-play oil-palm plantation outfit, with a target price of 20,610 rupiah, or 51% above the firm's current stock price of IDR13,750, thanks to higher palm- oil prices and better yields. It's expected to report over 50% earnings growth this year. ($1=9,060 rupiah.)   Also appealing: consumer plays like Unilever Indonesia (UNVR.ID), the local arm of the consumer-goods giant. Although the stock is up 60% over 12 months and is selling at 22.7 times this year's earnings, Citigroup sees 20% annualized earnings growth over the next two years. Then there's Astra International (ASII.ID), a large car assembler.   Macquarie Research's Liny Halim sees Indonesian banks as an excellent proxy for the expanding economy. Despite falling interest rates, Indonesian banks have huge net interest margins -- by far Asia's biggest. She has a Buy on Bank Niaga (BNGA.ID), which is fetching just 12 times this year's net and has 10% of the local mortgage market: "We see the local mortgage market growing 20% annually over the next three years, and expect Niaga to maintain its share."   Jakarta stocks have "had a great run since 2000, and early investors [who] bought banks have more than quadrupled their investments over a five-year period," notes Manu Bhaskaran, an economist at Centennial Group in Singapore.   There are no Indonesia-only exchange-traded funds, but U.S. investors can choose from Asia-focused funds as well as American depositary receipts, such as those of Telkom (TLK) and Indosat (IIT), or can get a broader exposure through the NYSE-listed closed-end Indonesia Fund (IF).   In any case, Indonesia's time has come. "China and India have been on the radar for a while," says Bhaskaran. "Investors are only just beginning to focus on markets like Indonesia."   ---   Assif Shameen covers the Southeast Asian markets from Singapore.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Flying Very Close To The Sun
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   First Solar may get singed.   The clean-tech darling saw its shares skyrocket more than 20 points Monday, hitting an all-time high of 119.85, after disclosing new European and North American contracts worth about $1.28 billion over five years.   The jump is reminiscent of Amazon.com's rise in the halcyon days when the book merchandiser would pump out hyperbole about increasing "eyeballs" and "wallet share." The responses from analysts who follow First Solar seemed downright Blodget-esque. ThinkEquity Partners analyst Paul Cheng raised his price target to 115 from 80 (Friday's close of 115.97 already topped that level) based on an earnings-per-share estimate of $5.39 for the year 2012. That's five years from now!   Cheng considers First Solar a "star of tomorrow" whose valuation profile during its "high-growth phase is not dissimilar to some of the biggest gainers of the past 15 years." And he writes: "We believe that investors applying only traditional metrics to value First Solar could be shortchanging themselves."   The facts are: First Solar boasts more than a $8 billion market value on about $400 million in expected 2007 revenues and 53 cents in earnings per share. At 115, it is trading at 96 times 2008 earnings and 14 times sales.   Cheng told Barron's last week that "Many contracts extend through 2012 and about 60% of those revenues are guaranteed," which gives him confidence in his projections.   First Solar may not be quite what it seems. The company, initially funded by a venture-capital firm run by the late Wal-Mart scion John T. Walton, is perceived as "thin-solar," dubbed Solar 2.0. The first generation of photovoltaic solar -- which uses cells to convert light from the sun directly into electricity -- relied on polysilicon, or sand, that is turned into glass, making for thick, heavy panels that nonetheless could be set on a roof because they didn't require too much surface area.   Thin-solar relies on chemicals and vapor deposition to lay down thin layers of film over a broad surface area. Because it's so light and flexible, it can be incorporated into building materials such as roof tiles, turning roofs into big solar panels.   The dirty secret on First Solar is that it uses thin-solar technology, but the film is still applied to heavy glass that resembles earlier generation panels, says Brion Tanous, analyst at Merriman Curhan Ford in San Francisco. Consequently, "A vast majority of First Solar's products are panels mounted on the ground because they are too heavy for rooftops, which suggests that it's not a true thin-film technology," Tanous argues.   To be sure, First Solar's approach is more cost-effective than many first-generation solar competitors, but it falls short of the huge potential for Solar 2.0. (For more on solar stocks, see Tech Trader Daily at Barron's Online, July 9).   First Solar didn't respond to queries last week.   Another problem: First Solar is highly dependent on European government subsidies, especially in Germany. Just two weeks ago, the German environment minister confirmed that he wants to cut subsidies further for solar. The news hit European solar shares, but went largely unnoticed on Wall Street.   Deutsche Bank alternative-energy analyst Steve O'Rourke seems to be a voice of reason. He initiated coverage of First Solar last week with a Hold and a price target of 90. He acknowledges that the company is an industry leader but says the "present valuation is stretched." And that isn't a stretch.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Aiming High And Scoring Big
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Barron's has kept a scorecard since early 2004, when we tallied the performance of our 2003 stock selections. So far, we've beaten the market every year. The bullish group from 2005 was up 38% through the middle of 2007, against a 27.9% rise inthe relevant benchmarks.   We assess our performance twice a year, taking a preliminary look at our first-half picks each July, and measuring the returns on the prior year's selected stocks in January. The table on the following page shows the performance of the companies that were profiled positively and negatively in the first half of 2007.   On our Website, www.barrons.com, you'll find free of charge our 2006 report card, which arguably says more about our stock-selection abilities and track record. That's because an average of a year has elapsed since we wrote about these companies, long enough to allow for a better determination about whether we were right or wrong in our views. That said, it could take another six months to get a more definitive reading on our late 2006 selections.   We generally have achieved more impressive results in the past with our bullish stock selections than with our bearish ones. But the situation changed this year, as 16 of the 18 stocks upon which we cast a skeptical eye in the first six months of 2007 ran into trouble. The 18 were down an average of 11.9% through June 29, against a 3.1% gain in the benchmark indexes -- an especially gratifying record, considering that even the best money managers have found it tough to make money shorting stocks.   The bearish group from 2006, some 32 stocks, was down an average of 4.4% through June 29, versus a gain of 14.2% for the relevant indexes. That compares handsomely to the performance of hedge funds that both buy stocks and sell them short. The hedgies' short positions rose 17.7% in '06, according to a recent speech by Byron Wien, the chief investment strategist at Pequot Capital Management. Call our showing luck or skill; we'll say skill.   The purpose of our scorecards is to inform readers about our success and failures in highlighting under- and overvalued stocks. Barron's isn't an investment newsletter; we aim to write well-researched, insightful and engaging stories on a wide range of investment-oriented topics, although we're aware many readers turn to these pages for specific investment ideas. We intend to continue our semiannual scorecards, whether the results flatter us or not.   A note on our methodology: Rather than comparing the performance of all the companies we write about to the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the most popular stock-market benchmark for institutional investors, we benchmark mid-sized companies against the S&P MidCap 400, and small ones against the Russell 2000. We use the S&P 500 as a yardstick for large companies and foreign concerns. The relative performance of our bullish and bearish selections in the year's first half can't be compared directly to the six-month performance of these indexes, because we measure the gain or loss in each stock from its closing price on the Friday preceding publication. Each stock gets an equal weighting in our calculations.     The top performers among our bullish picks this year include industrial stocks such as McDermott International, Siemens, Timken, Textron and Joy Global, as well as a buyout target, Manor Care. This shouldn't come as a surprise, given that two of the biggest investment themes in 2007 have been global economic expansion and the leveraged-buyout boom.   No. 1-ranked McDermott, a global engineering and construction company, rose 41%, to 83, from 59 when our story ran in May. Since June 29, our cut-off date for calculating the report card, McDermott has rallied to 89. The company reported strong first-quarter results subsequent to our article, which prompted analysts to lift their 2007 and 2008 profit estimates. McDermott's marine-construction division is being buoyed by growing energy demand, which is lifting orders for offshore oil rigs and undersea pipelines.   The biggest loser among our bullish selections this year is Starbucks, which has fallen about 16%, to 26, since our positive write-up in March. Last month, Starbucks' chief financial officer said it will be "very challenging" for the company to hit the upper end of its profit estimate of 87-to-89 cents a share for the fiscal year ending in September. Wall Street has been cooling to Starbucks, which is down 35% from its record high of 40 set last November. Investors' fears center on the company's aggressive expansion plans and the possible saturation of the U.S. market.   Starbucks is no busted growth stock, however. Its earnings per share are expected to rise 20% this year and another 20%, to $1.06 a share, in fiscal 2008. The stock now trades for under 25 times estimated fiscal 2008 earnings.   Retailing has been a tough sector this year, and we've gotten burned so far with two companies: Bed, Bath and Beyond and Office Depot. Both have had earnings disappointments since our bullish articles -- but the good news is that either one could be a buyout candidate.   For this report card, we focus only on company-specific stories in Barron's, excluding broader industry assessments and the stocks featured by our market columnists, who do their own assessments annually.   By excluding industry pieces, however, we've probably understated our results. The average gain for the five stocks discussed in a bullish Jan. 15, 2007, story on TV-station operators has been 60%.   We also were bullish on offshore-drilling companies in April; stocks featured then, like Diamond Offshore Drilling (DO) and Transocean (RIG), are each up more than 25%.   Among our bearish selections for 2007, International Fight League, Jones Soda, Medifast and Blackstone Group fell sharply from their publication dates through the end of June. Money-losing International Fight League promotes a brutal sport called mixed martial arts, combining aspects of wrestling, boxing and karate. The sport is illegal in many states, and the company's shares are trading below $1, versus $3 when our May article was published.   We wondered whether Jones Soda was a fad stock, selling at an excessive multiple, relative to its prospective earnings. Its shares dropped to $14 by June 29, from $21 when our story ran in late May. Our bearish June cover story on Blackstone generated attention because we argued that its stock was richly priced and that the buyout mania might be peaking. Blackstone has fallen to 29 from 35 since then.   Our bearish call on AT&T in a January cover story doesn't look too prescient, with the stock up 16% since then. AT&T and rival Verizon Communications (VZ) are back in favor on Wall Street. Investors like their wireless businesses, and are worrying less about the loss of traditional phone lines and the threat from cable operators.   We had some big winners among our bullish calls from 2006. Apple Computer (AAPL), Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT), Garmin (GRMN), American Real Estate Partners (ACP) and Ping An Insurance (2318.Hong Kong), one of China's largest life insurers, all have more than doubled since our articles ran. But we've flipped our view on American Real Estate Partners, controlled by billionaire investor Carl Icahn. We argued that the stock looked attractive in February 2006 at 34, but felt it was overvalued in April at 108. It now trades around 104.   Investors seem excited that American Real Estate could win control of Lear (LEA), the auto-parts maker. Lear holders are due to vote this week on whether to accept Icahn's offer to buy the company for $37.25 a share. The bid, which was sweetened by $1.25 a share last week, has provoked opposition from some Lear holders, who argue that it undervalues the company.   Our two worst bullish calls last year were on XM Satellite Radio (XMSR) and McClatchy (MNI), each down around 50%. We failed to anticipate the slowdown in subscriber additions at XM, and the company's weakening financial prospects. XM and its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio (SIRI), announced merger plans earlier this year, but investors fear that antitrust regulators will block the transaction.   We erred in our positive take on McClatchy's deal to buy Knight-Ridder, just before a sharp fall-off in newspaper advertising that has stung the debt-laden California publisher.   Our bearish calls in 2006 on Pegasus Wireless, Vonage, SulphCo and Vertex Pharmaceuticals have been followed by sharp declines in their stocks. But our bearish cover story on Google in February 2006 looks bad. The stock has since climbed nearly 50%. We've been bullish on rival Yahoo! (YHOO), which has fallen 10% since our May 2006 cover story. So far, we've bet on the wrong Internet horse.   Our worst bearish call from 2006 was on Pre-Paid Legal Services (PPD), which sells legal-service plans to individuals through Avon-style marketers. The company continues to defy its critics, who believe its method of attracting sales associates is deceptive. Pre-Paid, which says that its recruiting is proper, saw its profits rise 53% last year to $3.51 a share, and 29%, to $1.08, in 2007's first quarter. The stock has doubled to 70 since our skeptical story in April 2006.   Fortunately for Barron's readers, such huge missteps have been rare.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Crt Rules German Train Drivers Are Allowed To Strike
Story: (Updates with union response)     BERLIN (AP)--German national railway train drivers are allowed to strike as part of demands for higher wages, a labor court ruled Saturday, repealing an injunction imposed last week.   The GDL union, which represents many drivers for Deutsche Bahn AG, and is seeking wage increases of up to 31% for some of its members, welcomed the ruling.   "We expected this ruling," GDL head Manfred Schell said, adding that the union won't stage any strikes before Thursday, when both sides meet for the next round of talks.   Last week, Deutsche Bahn sought a court injunction to prevent walkouts by the drivers, after they staged two several-hour strikes that brought parts of the network to a standstill. But a labor court in Mainz repealed that, paving the way for the possibility of new strikes.   Deutsche Bahn is offering GDL the same deal it reached with two other unions. That agreement, reached on Monday, foresees a 4.5% pay rise Jan. 1 and one-time payments of EUR600 ($826) to cover the second half of this year.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 14:26 ET (18:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Tchenguiz Acquires Stake In Bramdean Alternatives - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Property entrepreneur Vincent Tchenguiz has bought a 29.9% stake in a new vehicle run by "city super mum" Nicola Horlick's Bramdean Asset Management, the Financial Times reported Saturday without citing sources.   Tchenguiz's family trusts paid GBP40 million at an issue price of 100p a share in Bramdean Alternatives (BRAL.LN), a new alternative investments fund, the newspaper said.    According to the FT, a representative for Consensus Business Group, Tchenguiz's investment company, said the fund's intended portfolio strategy, particularly its emphasis on infrastructure investments, made it very appealing.   Bramdean Alternatives, which began trading on the London Stock Exchange this week, aims to hold 50% of its funds in private equity, 30% in hedge funds and 20% in other specialty funds, including real estate and infrastructure funds, the newspaper reported.   The fund raised GBP131 million from institutional and high net worth private investors, well short of its GBP250 million target but nearly double its GBP70 million minimum, the FT added.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 09:46 ET (13:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Activist Holders Push Alcoa To Opt For Takeover - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Activist shareholders in Alcoa Inc. (AA) are pushing the aluminum producer to seek a sale or break-up, The Times in London reported Saturday, citing shareholders.   Shareholders are hopeful that a deal worth potentially more than $50 billion can be reached with either BHP Billiton Ltd. (BHP) or Brazil's Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (RIO), or CVRD, the newspaper said.   According to The Times, hedge fund investors have taken large positions in Alcoa in recent months as speculation mounts that it will become a target for one of the large mining groups.   A number of these shareholders said they are demanding meetings with Alcoa executives to force the company into a deal, The Times added.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 12:03 ET (16:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Plugged In: A Fiberoptic Burning Too Bright
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   The fiberoptic resurgence that has lit the way for new public stocks in the past nine months is real. It's also fragile, and as a result, some of those stocks are running far ahead of the rosiest outlook for their businesses.   Case in point: Infinera, which had a $182 million initial public offering on June 7. Its stock popped 52% that day and, at a recent $24.99, is up 27% since then.   Seven-year-old Infinera (ticker: INFN), which started life as Zepton Networks,makes equipment used by phone companies to expand their networks' bandwidth. It has a promising future, with sales hitting nearly $50 million in the most recent quarter. And it's finally generating positive cash flow, despite continued net losses. But even with a dramatic rise in sales this year and next, it would be hard to justify the company's current 20 times multiple, based on price-to-trailing 12-month sales -- a valuation that seems to assume unreasonable growth in the fiberoptic market.   Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Infinera is one of four recent fiberoptic IPOs. Judging by the others' track records, one might see Infinera at a cheaper price soon. The threesome -- Opnext (OPXT), Optium (OPTM) and IPG Photonics (IPGP) -- have traded down as much as 25% from their initial closing prices.   That's not to say that their prospects aren't encouraging. Some of the most astute luminaries of networking say that fiberoptic deployments that cratered in the dot-com era's implosion now are being rebooted. "The world didn't end in 2000," says Len Bosack, a co-founder of Cisco Systems (CSCO) who is running a fiberoptic equipment start-up called XKL. "Storage is continuing to get less expensive , people are using computers more and more in their businesses, and all these things have driven an increase in bandwidth demand."   But it's a tenuous recovery. The global market for optical equipment was just $9.2 billion last year, less than a quarter the size of that for cellular telephone equipment, for example, and smaller than either the network-router or Ethernet-switch markets dominated by Cisco, according to data from industry research firm Dell'Oro Group of Redwood City, Calif.   True, Dell'Oro forecasts that Infinera's corner of the market, so-called wavelength division multiplexing, should see sales rise a healthy 22% this year. But that multiple of 20 times trailing sales still suggests that the stock is way ahead of those prospects.   Assuming Infinera's sales triple in the next 12 months, the stock, at its recent price of $25.64, would still be trading at a very rich 7 multiple of trailing sales, far in excess of Ciena's (CIEN) 4.7 times, despite 20% projected sales growth for much larger Ciena next year.   To be sure, Infinera is unlikely to repeat the worst excesses of the dot-com days. The company's net loss on sales of $49.2 million in its March quarter was only 9% above the year-earlier $19.8 million deficit. And it turned a gross profit of $11.9 million, or 26% of sales, while adding cash to its books.   Infinera is a promising company in a revitalized industry. But to go whole-hog on its pricey stock seems foolish at a time when fiberoptics is just crawling back to respectability.   ---   A version of this story appeared July 11 on Barron's Online.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Market Watch: A Sampling Of Advisory Opinion
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen     MarketWatch   Buyback Battle Rages   Economic Research   by BMO Capital Markets     100 King St. W., Toronto, Ontario M5X 1H3     July 11: The battle between slower earnings growth and buyback support continued [Tuesday]. This time, it was Home Depot on the front line, shelling out an $11 billion share buyback in defense of its housing-related earnings slowdown. The net effect of a reduced earnings outlook and a material buyback announcement was a stock that inched up 2 cents; casualty averted. With coffers of cash, Corporate America is showing that it has the artillery to fight the earnings slowdown and keep share prices elevated, if only temporarily. . . .   The U.S. dollar [was] trying to claw its way out of the doldrums [after hitting] a record low versus the euro and a one-month low against the yen after two ratings agencies -- S&P and Moody's -- were reportedly downgrading a large quantity of residential mortgage-backed securities. The British pound [reached] a 26-year high. The yen was a bit weaker on some disappointing price data. . . . The yuan continued to strengthen to its highest level since the revaluation.   -- Robert Kavcic, Jennifer Lee     What Goldilocks Brings   Weekly Investment Report   by Allegiant Asset Management     1900 E. 9th St., Cleveland, Ohio 44114     July 10: The stock market has been rallying without the help of P/E expansion. Lower interest rates by the Fed could be the catalyst for higher price-earnings ratios. So, what could be the catalyst for P/E expansion? While there are several possible candidates (including increasing global liquidity, declining inflation and growing demographic demand for financial assets), we believe the most likely catalyst for P/E expansion is lower interest rates by the Fed.   The Federal Reserve has been on hold for a year, since moving to a restrictive monetary policy. At 5.25%, the current fed-funds rate is clearly restrictive (neutral would be around 4%). The Fed's "Goldilocks" outlook anticipates the economy's gradual return to full potential, as inflation subsides to the Fed's preferred target range. Should this scenario occur, the Fed would be in a position to lower interest rates back to neutral, having met its policy objectives.   Recent data suggest we are firmly on the Goldilocks path. The economy, as measured by gross domestic product . . . [dropped to] +0.7% for 1Q07. Most indicators suggest the economy is now rebounding from that low reading. As for inflation, the Fed's preferred gauge of inflation, core PCE [personal-consumption expenditure], has been moving lower. . . . We seem to be on the path toward lower interest rates by the Fed.   -- Brian Stine     Will Bonds Squeeze Stocks?   Mega Change, Mortgage Woes,   Real Estate and the Markets   by the Aden Forecast     P.O. Box 790260, St. Louis, Mo. 63179     July: The number of people who may lose their homes [has] hit a record high, with subprime borrowers leading the way; lenders say 15 million more homes may end up being foreclosed. That's increasing the supply . . . [as] demand is falling. . . . If the mega-upward-reversal in interest rates stays intact, then interest rates and mortgage rates are going much higher in the years ahead. . . . This also means bond prices are going much lower . . . over the next decade or two. That'll likely keep downward pressure on stocks, and suggests big inflation is eventually coming. . . . Producer prices have already been surging over the past seven months, at a nearly 10% annualized rate.   -- Mary Anne and Pamela Aden   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: UK Police: 11 Tesco Markets Closed On Security Alert
Story: (Updates with report by manager of store near Glasgow, employee report that police said there was a bomb threat)     LONDON (AP)--U.K. police closed at least 11 Tesco PLC (TSCDY) supermarkets across the country Saturday because of a security alert, authorities said.   The manager at a Tesco in Barrhead, near Glasgow, told U.K.'s Press Association that staff were sent home around 12:30 p.m. (1330 GMT) after a power failure. But an unidentified employee at a neighboring shop said police had told him there had been a bomb threat.   Police in Hertfordshire, where the U.K.'s largest supermarket has its headquarters, said no one had been hurt and that the move was a precaution. Police didn't immediately give further details.   "Police are investigating a series of incidents in a number of locations across the country involving Tesco stores," a Hertfordshire police spokeswoman said on condition of anonymity in line with force police. "These stores have been temporarily closed as a precaution for public safety."   Tesco said the police had responded to a number of incidents.   "Police are investigating and so we are unable to comment further," she said on condition of anonymity in line with company policy. "As always, at all times customer welfare is our priority."   Police said the closures affected stores in London, other locations in England, Scotland and Wales.   A spokesman for South Wales police said the Tesco store at Riverside, Port Talbot, had been closed since Saturday afternoon and said officers would remain at the store for as long as necessary.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 15:05 ET (19:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) The Electronic Investor: Get Ready To Structure Your Portfolio
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Theresa W. Carey   Structured products are the fastest-growing investment class in the U.S., according to their aptly named advocacy and trade group, the Structured Products Association. Although they're not available on-line as yet, they will be before too long, and investors should be aware of their role in a portfolio.   Common in Europe, these are synthetic investments that are usually offered in the form of a bond or note with some guarantee about principal protection. Their payouts, which are generally higher than standard fixed-income securities, are tied to the performance of assets like equities, commodities, and currencies or indexes linked to them. As a result, they carry more risk. Investors buy them to meet needs, like hedging stock or currency positions, that aren't readily available in single financial instruments.     "Structured products are to Europeans what mutual funds are to U.S. investors," says Keith Styrcula, the founder and chairman of the SPA trade group (www.structuredproducts.org). His organization estimates that approximately $194 billion in structured products were held in retail-investment accounts in Europe in 2006, versus $64 billion in U.S. accounts.   Styrcula believes that U.S. sales could hit $100 billion in 2007. Granted, that's not much compared to the $1 trillion mutual-fund market, but as he points out, the robust size of the funds' market "didn't happen all at once."   Currently, structured products (SPs) are most likely to be found in the portfolios of wealthy investors who have set up separately managed accounts. They can be used as part of the asset-allocation process to diversify or limit risk exposure of a portfolio, or as an alternative to a direct investment, usually through the use of a derivative like an option or for added leverage. They carry names like equity growth-linked securities, equity basket-linked certificates of deposit or index-linked notes, depending on the issuer, most of whom are major investment banks such as Merrill Lynch.   Fidelity, Schwab, Northern Trust, Claymore, LPL and Nuveen all have set up new SP distribution divisions in the last 18 months to handle more of these instruments, says Styrcula.   The potential to have principal protected, or mostly protected, for long-lifecycle investments is a particular draw right now. "There's a lot of room for SPs to take share away from the variable-annuity market," says Styrcula, who claims they're cheaper and more effective in meeting retirees' needs. In his view, SPs "are like ETFs with passive payouts. It's the next generation of [exchange-traded fund] investing."   But you can't just log into your online brokerage account and find these instruments -- yet. There are some structured products built into a handful of mutual funds, however. For example, Fidelity Strategic Real Return Fund (ticker: FSRRX) has elements that could be considered "structured products," since 25% of the fund is described as "commodity-linked notes and related investments -- structured notes whose performance is tied to the returns of the Dow Jones AIG Commodities Index."   One issue preventing more widespread adoption of SPs is their black-box pricing. It's not always obvious what the components of a particular SP are and the pricing can be opaque because various securities' prices are included. If derivatives are involved, the terms can be even more complex.     We're seeing software developers jump into the market, which should make pricing more transparent, possibly speeding their adoption. For instance, NumeriX (http://www.numerix.com), which publishes pricing and risk analytics for fixed income, credit, foreign exchange and equity, announced that Bloomberg has embedded NumeriX analytics within a select set of Bloomberg Professional service calculators that should make pricing more readily understandable.   Kevin Sanborn, NumeriX's senior vice president for integration, says these tools provide technology that should makes the market more comprehensible to the masses. "This is a technology to make the structure of the products more exciting and more accessible," he says.   NumeriX, which offers other pricing analytics too, is also discussing putting a version of its calculator on the SPA's Website to provide real-time pricing of various structured instruments.   When will you see structured products featured on your online broker's site? If Styrcula has his way, soon.   ---   e-mail: electronicinvestor@yahoo.com.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Heiress Ivanka Trump To Join Trump Entertainment Resorts Bd
Story: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP)--Heiress Ivanka Trump will join the board of Trump Entertainment Resorts Inc. (TRMP).   She currently is a vice president with the Trump Organization, which controls Trump hotels, real estate holdings and golf courses, and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, one of the nation's top business schools.   Before joining the board, Ivanka Trump must get a license from the state Casino Control Commission. The agency is expected to grant her preliminary approval as soon as Wednesday.   Casino regulators will conduct a background check to make sure she has done nothing that would disqualify her from holding a gambling license.   She is the daughter of Donald Trump.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 16:02 ET (20:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Trouble In The Heartland?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   A large but little-known lender to rural America could be due for a major downgrade by the top debt-rating agencies.   Independent credit rater Egan-Jones figures that the bonds of the National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corp. -- rated the equivalent of single-A by Moody's, Standard & Poor's and Fitch- -- should actually be a full seven notches lower, at single-B-plus, which is junk.   Egan-Jones, which made its name with early warnings on Enron, WorldCom and other disasters, cites steadily declining net interest-income at the finance concern and scant provisions against loan losses. The cooperative, which is known as CFC and mainly extends low-cost credit to electric utilities, has a loan portfolio of some $17.5 billion.   Any trimming of the debt ratings by the big agencies could hurt the company's preferred stock. Because CFC operates as a non-profit, it has no common stock, but its preferred shares yielding 7.45% are available to investors because they are listed on the New York Stock Exchange (ticker: NRN).   "We're not saying it's going to go bankrupt," says Sean Egan, managing director at the rating firm, which has rated the cooperative since 1998. But, he says, the company "shouldn't be an investment-grade credit."   In a nutshell, Egan-Jones isn't comfortable giving the company an investment-grade rating because its net interest income -- the difference between the interest it earns on loans and the interest it pays on its borrowings -- dropped to $20.9 million in the first nine months of fiscal 2007 from of $300.7 million in all of fiscal 2002. At the same time, CFC's loan-loss provision -- the quarterly addition to reserves -- has fallen to zero.   Perhaps most tellingly, the cooperative's net interest income is a meager 0.1% of net loans. In comparison, that ratio is 4.8%, after loan-loss provisions, for single-A-rated CIT Group (CIT), a commercial and consumer finance company that lends to various industries.   Given CFC's tight lending margins, "it's basically in breakeven mode," Egan contends. In addition, "it's ludicrous for any financial institution" not to make loan-loss provisions, says Egan, noting that National Rural Utilities has listed $1 billion in problem loans in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   Officials at National Rural Utilities, not surprisingly, dispute Egan-Jones' analysis, calling it "inaccurate and incomplete." The cooperative's decisions on taking provisions for loan losses "are not arbitrary," says CEO Sheldon Petersen. Rather, they're based on a formula that includes internal credit ratings, credit histories and recovery rates, and is confirmed by the company's auditing firm. Nearly all of its loans are secured both by assets and the borrower's revenue streams, he adds. And since most of its borrowers are electricity providers, an "essential service," future revenues are pretty much a given.   The company also has some $611 million set aside in reserves -- plus $3.3 billion in revolving credit facilities.   As a finance company, CFC depends heavily on good credit ratings, because the higher the rating, the cheaper the cost of raising money to lend out to members. And in the event of a bankruptcy -- however unlikely --  preferred shares are subordinate to its debt outstanding and would be at the back of the creditors' line. Its 7.45% shares, at $25 each, currently trade around par, or full value.   Although created by the Agriculture Department in 1969, the cooperative doesn't carry any "implied" government guarantee, as the government-chartered mortgage giants Fannie Mae (FNM) and Freddie Mac (FRE) do. Yet as a non-profit, unlike the mortgage giants, it has no worries about maximizing shareholder value.   Still, Egan-Jones says, look at CFC's bottom line. Its most recent quarterly filing with the SEC is for its fiscal third quarter, ended Feb. 28, when it reported net interest income of $20.9 million after making no provision for loan losses. A year ago, it reported a loss of $6.1 million after a $19.6 million loan-loss provision.   The third-quarter income statement also includes $40.97 million in derivative cash settlements as part of earnings. But Egan cries foul on this, saying it should be a separate item. "It's not recurring; it's not a dependable source of income," he argues.   Removing the gain from derivatives and including a provision for loan losses would pretty much wipe out the cooperative's quarterly earnings of $52.2 million. A year ago, it reported a loss of $21.9 million.   But CEO Petersen says that his company uses derivatives only as a hedge against interest rates involving the swapping of fixed- and floating-rate debt. "It's matching assets and liabilities," he says, and perfectly appropriate to count as earnings. The company doesn't trade or make markets in derivatives.   Moody's, for its part, recently reiterated on an implicit basis its A1 senior secured rating on National Rural Utilities when it affirmed the rating on a $5.1 million bond issue by Great River Energy. Moody's rating on National Rural's preferred shares is two notches lower at A3.   "There's more predictability" with the not-for-profit because a majority of its members can raise rates without needing government approval, unlike most investor-owned utilities, says A.J. Sabatelle, a senior credit officer at Moody's. Since it was formed in 1969, the cooperative has had losses on loans totaling just $117 million, Sabatelle says.   S&P has attributed its single-A rating to CFC's "strong market position in the rural utilities lending industry" and "low loan losses despite high levels of nonperforming and restructured loans." Fitch in February raised to positive its outlook on the cooperative's single-A rating, citing, among other things, "improvements in risk management."   Still, Egan-Jones is worth hearing out. Unlike Moody's, S&P and Fitch, Egan-Jones is an independent credit-rating agency that is paid by investors, not by bond issuers, for ratings, removing a potential conflict of interest between the rater and the rated.
