Egan-Jones doesn't know its clients' market positions in equities and/or credit-default swaps and "we don't want to know," says Egan.   Egan-Jones, which uses only public information in determining a rating, appears on track to gain approval by the SEC to be a nationally recognized statistical rating organization, a designation already bestowed to Moody's, S&P, Fitch and Toronto-based Dominion Bond Rating Service.   So far, Egan-Jones is a lone voice in the bond market warning about CFC. But if history is any guide, others may soon be singing the same tune.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) The Trader: Wall Street Shops At -2-
Story: There are other catalysts, too. Because partner GlaxoSmithKline's bestselling Imitrex will become a generic drug by late 2008, "we believe GSK intends to aggressively convert its Imitrex sales" -- about $1.1 billion in the U.S. last year -- "to Trexima in order to capture significant market share in the migraine market before its Imitrex sales are at risk," Lu says. Trexima sales pegged at $53 million this year could reach $571 million in 2010, and Pozen's 5% royalty jumps to 17% in 2010 and after.   But because Trexima is Pozen's primary candidate, any regulatory glitch can send shares tumbling to 7 or 8. Given that slim but real risk, bulls might consider buying August call options or call spreads on Pozen. Headline: Barron's(7/16) The Striking Price: Putting A Bull's-Eye On Buyout Targets
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mohammed Hadi   Feeling left out of the buyout boom? Tired of your brother-in-law gloating over the fact that he was "smart" enough to pick the next target of private-equity buyers?   The options market lets the adventurous play the mergers and acquisitions game by selling puts on buyout targets.   A put seller takes the view that a stock is going to remain above a certain price -- the option's strike price -- until after the option expires. But put-selling comes with a big risk: If the underlying stock falls, put sellers have to buy it and could wind up being forced to overpay.   Of course, just because someone is planning to buy a company doesn't eliminate the risk that the stock could retreat -- but it certainly waters it down.   There's good money to be made selling these contracts -- far better returns than you'd get buying the stock and waiting for a deal to close, says William Lefkowitz, chief options strategist at vFinance Investments and a habitual put seller. "It's my favorite thing to do."   Trading last week provided two great illustrations of the pros and cons of the put selling approach.   Pro: Although many expected a buyer to rival Alcoa's (ticker: AA) bid for Alcan (AL), traders could still sell the January 75 Alcan puts for as much as a dollar on Wednesday. By Friday, with Alcan signing a deal with Rio Tinto (RTP) for $101 per share, those puts were worth as little as 25 cents, a threefold return to the put sellers in just two days.   Con: Sellers of puts on SLM (the old Sallie Mae) recently had a heart-stopping moment. The stock plunged nearly 10% after a group that plans to buy SLM said pending federal law could put the deal in jeopardy. The SLM deal is for $60 a share; as the stock fell Wednesday to $52.15, from $57.80 the day before, January 50 puts on the stock surged to a high of $2.50 from as little as 70 cents. Traders who kept their nerve probably made out OK once the stock recovered ground -- but it's a great example of a deal where hefty put prices likely reflect risks to stay away from.   Lefkowitz thinks that there are other such opportunities -- if you have the confidence that the announced deals will close.   Deals that might take years to close offer also the chance to be a repeat offender. For example, Lefkowitz is still selling puts on Harrah's Entertainment (HET) and getting a fair amount for these nearly a year after that deal was first announced (see Striking Price, Oct. 9, 2006).   With the stock at $85.65, and the bid for the company at $90, Lefkowitz suggests selling January 75 puts, now going for about $1 -- which means any seller of these must be willing to pay $75 for Harrah's if the deal unwinds, but at an effective price of $74, nearly 14% below the current price.     With most of Corporate America putting the finishing touches on their quarterly-earnings statements, the options market has started to handicap the potential for these reports to move stocks. For traders willing to bet against the market, that means opportunities abound.   Goldman Sachs options strategist John Marshall last week screened for companies on which options are either overestimating or underestimating the size of a post-earnings-report stock move. Because the estimation of a coming stock move is a key part of option prices, traders who think there's no good reason for the discrepancy can profit by either buying or selling options.   There are a few standouts. Options on Amazon.com (AMZN), for example, have been pricing-in a swing, higher or lower, of about 10%, once the company's earnings report comes out on July 25. The average, Marshall notes, over the past eight quarters has been 13%, and consider the fact that last quarter the stock rose nearly 27% the day after the company's earnings were released.   So what's a trader to do here? Buy options. What you buy depends on what your view on Amazon is, Marshall explained. So if you think the stock is overpriced, buy puts; undervalued, buy calls; or neither, then buy both.   On the flip side, Marshall points to a smaller stock: Amdocs. Citing Goldman's IT-services analyst, he thinks coming earnings statements for the software and services company will be less of an event than the options market is currently pricing in. And, importantly, Amdocs (DOX) is not likely to be taken out in the near term, the analyst believes.   So consider selling a combination of both the August 40 puts and the August 40 call options. Right now, that can fetch about $3, which means the straddle sellers will profit as long as DOX remains between $37 (or about 6.8% below the current price of $39.69) and $43 (or about 8% above the current price) before these expire.   The average move this stock has made following the last eight earnings reports is 2%, Marshall notes.   Still, caveats abound. Option selling carries risks. If you can't stomach them, don't do it.   ---   Mohammed Hadi is a reporter at Dow Jones Newswires in Jersey City, N.J.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Providence, KKR To Launch Virgin Media Bid - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Providence has entered the bidding war for Virgin Media Inc. (VMED), The Times of London reported Saturday without citing sources.   The U.S. buyout firm is understood to have joined with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., Blackstone Group (BX) and Cinven Group Ltd to enter the auction, the newspaper said.   Virgin Media last week received an approach from Carlyle Group L.P., whose $33- to $34-a-share offer values the U.K. cable company at $23 billion including its GBP6 billion of debt, the paper reported.   According to The Times a deadline for first-round indicative offers will be set for some time in August.   Carlyle, KKR, Blackstone and Cinven declined to comment, it added.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9448     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 11:40 ET (15:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Research Reports
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited by Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Anadigics   -- ANAD-NNM     Hold   -- Price 13.80 on July 11   by Think Equity Partners     Our price target, 13, represents 21 times our calendar-year '08 earnings-per-share estimate of 61 cents, in line with our projection for ANAD's '08 revenue growth of 20%. Risks [include]: Weakness in wireless-handset market; inability to win new customers for GSM [global system for mobile communication] products; and weakness in cable-infrastructure and set-top box markets . . . Anadigics has traditionally had 10%-plus of sales to LG [a global electronics firm].     BJ Services   -- BJS-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 28.64 on July 10   by Sterne Agee     BJS is primarily a provider of pressure pumping, roughly equally sharing the worldwide market with Halliburton and Schlumberger. The shares of all three declined significantly (28% to 38%) as Canadian gas producers dramatically cut drilling activity. While the other two have recovered, BJS' shares are still down [by] over one-third and now sell at a discount versus premium valuation. We believe that as the Canadian gas activity picks up . . . the current low valuation will have proven to be an attractive entry point. Target: 34.     CB Richard Ellis Group   -- CBG-NYSE     Strong Buy   -- Price 37.29 on July 11   by JMP Securities     We expect EPS to rise 45% during '07 to $2.15, due in part to accretive Trammell Crow purchase. For '08, we conservatively project 8% revenue growth, driving 19% EPS growth to $2.55 . . . Longer-term, we expect mid-high-single-digit revenue growth will drive 15%-20% EPS growth. CB currently trades at '07 and '08 price/earnings multiples of 17.3 times and 14.6 times, versus Jones Lang LaSalle at 20.5 and 17.9 times. CB's 2007 and 2008 [enterprise value/earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] multiples are 10.6 times and 9.3 times, compared to JLL at 12.5 times and 11.1 times. At our 48 price target, CB's 2008 P/E and EV/Ebitda multiples would be 18.8 times and 11.6 times.     Energy Transfer Partners   -- ETP-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 64 on July 11   by Morgan Keegan     ETP reported 71 cents EPS for Q3, versus the Street's 72 cents. But after adjusting for a $17.8 million profit (12 cents/unit) from interest-rate swaps, EPS comes in at 59 cents/unit, well below the Street and 6 cents/unit under our forecast. On a positive note, operating income was in line with our estimates. Transportation volumes were up 41% year-over-year, and operating income increased 40% y/y as recent capital expansions came on line. Although ETP missed our estimate and consensus, we are maintaining our estimate of $2.85 for FY07 until we receive some clarity from management. We are also keeping our total return estimates of an additional 7% to 10% for the rest of '07 and 37% to 42% by the end of '08. ETP owns and operates a diversified portfolio of midstream energy assets.     The Greenbrier Companies   -- GBX-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 33.15 on July 11   by McAdams Wright Ragen     Railcar-manufacturer Greenbrier reported adjusted fiscal 3Q earnings of $1 per share, which was better than our estimate of 58 cents and consensus of 42 cents. The stock gained 15.75% on the report. Revenues in the manufacturing and refurbishment divisions came in higher than we forecast, as did margins driving the upside. Our 4Q estimate stays at 58 cents; FY moves to $1.93, from $1.51. This does not include special charges registered during the year-mostly related to Canadian plant closure. The estimate for '08 moves from $2.25 to $2.40. GBX trades at 8.25 times estimated '07 Ebitda and 7.6 times forward Ebitda. On a P/E basis, [shares] trade at 17.2 times '07 earnings/13.8 times forward earnings.     Marshall & Ilsley   -- MI-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 45.84 on July 11   by Sandler O'Neill     MI [will] acquire First Indiana Corporation (FINB), a $2.1 billion bank . . . This all-cash deal, valued at roughly $529 million (expected to close in 4Q07 or 1Q08) . . . [or] only about 3.8% of MI's asset base and 4.3% of market-cap, strikes us as digestible for MI. Management expects 2-cent [dilution] to EPS in 2008 (about 0.5%) and accreti[on] thereafter . . . for the industry, we see balance-sheet growth, a tough rate environment and credit as fundamental headwinds . . . along with MI's premium valuation and ongoing merger/acquisition speculation, we . . . believe our Hold rating is best.     Phillips-Van Heusen   -- PVH-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 57.10 on July 10   by W.R. Hambrecht     The combination of strong sales and margin expansion should lead to GAAP EPS of $3.13 for F2007. For F2008, we [see] $3.72/share, an estimated 19% increase in earnings. At 70 price target, the P/E multiple would be about 18 times, with 19%-plus estimated EPS growth putting [price-earnings-growth] around 1 . . . PVH has reiterated its interest in utilizing cash to acquire [more] brands . . . Brands under strategic review at Liz Claiborne represent some potential candidates.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Profile: Black Box With Heart -2-
Story: Last year, Bridgeway's models seemed to short-circuit. Aggressive Investors 1 and 2 underperformed the S&P 500 by 8.68 and 10.35 percentage points, respectively. Montgomery minces few words about the debacle, noting ruefully that only one of the Aggressive Investors fund models -- a value measure -- per-formed well.   Yet, as he points out, Bridgeway has recovered nicely from other down periods, such as the back-to-back years of 1997 and 1998, when Aggressive Investors 1 faltered.   Then there was a six-month period in 1998 in which Ultra-Small Company was torched for a 50% loss.   In both cases, the funds roared back to lay waste to their respective indexes. And in both cases, some patience was needed.   "I have a high tolerance to bad periods and sleep quite well. We try to counsel our fund investors to have a long-term time horizon of at least three years, and it just pains me that some of our clients sold out late last year, rather than hanging around," Montgomery muses.   Indeed that would've been good advice. This year, through July 9, Aggressive Investors 2 was up 21.38%, almost triple the S&P's 7.5% advance.   The argument could be made that Bridgeway's success arises in part from the presence of small- and mid-cap stocks even in larger-cap funds like Aggressive Investors. In a market in which smaller stocks have outperformed so dramatically since 2000, that undoubtedly provided a boost.     The median stock-market value of Aggressive Investors 2's portfolio in 2002 was just half of its current level, $9.7 billion. Large-cap stocks then made up less than 25% of the total portfolio; today, they account for more than 46%. The fund was able to capture the curl of the small-stock surge. At the same time, its performance also hints that, perhaps, big-caps finally are back.   In addition, the models kept Aggressive Investors 1 from crashing and burning in the post-2000 collapse of the Bubble Market after the fund had returned 120.62% during the 1999 blow-off.   Over the following three years, it not only avoided the Nasdaq's 75% death dive, but also annually outpaced the S&P. "During 1999, the models made us pare our tech positions from two-thirds to about a third of the portfolio," Montgomery recalls. "As a result, we were about the only member of the triple-digit-return club of 1999 to survive."   The larger Aggressive Investors 2 fund's latest top 10 holdings (as of March 31) reflect the models eclectic selections.   Montgomery isn't one for personal flash. He still lives in a modest four-bedroom home just three blocks from his office. What he likes to call his "yacht" is a second-hand 15-foot boat that he keeps stored near Galveston Island.   "In the end, it's not the size of the bank account that counts but the love and relationships that one achieves in life," he observes.   A worthy sentiment, to be sure. And one that many of Bridgeway's investors would endorse, even as their bank accounts expand.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) Fund Of Information: Ariel Gets Its Groove Back
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   What have you done for me lately?   That's what impatient investors may have wanted to ask the flagship funds at Ariel Capital Management, a Chicago money manager known for value investing.   But as performance improves, the question now is whether those investors who left will wait too long to get back in -- as they often do. Ariel Fund (ticker: ARGFX), which is in Morningstar's mid-cap blend category, has a one-year return of 27.5%, besting 60% of its peers. Its three-year annual return of 12.7% isn't terrible in absolute terms, but trails more than 90% of its Morningstar peers. It's similar for the five-year return, 14.3%, which puts it in the category's bottom 20%.   The fund, however, has a strong long-term record: Its 10-year annual return of 12.9% places in the top 20%.   Ariel Appreciation (CAAPX), which has more of a large-cap tilt but is in the mid-cap blend box, has a similar performance history.   The underperformance within the category no doubt triggered net outflows, which for the two funds totaled about $1.8 billion last year, according to Financial Research Corp. This year, the outflows have slowed to a combined $550 million through May.   Ariel Appreciation's assets total about $2.75 billion. The Ariel Fund is bigger, with about $4.3 billion. The lead manager for both funds is John Rogers, a staunch value-investing practitioner who likes to buy and hold quality companies that he and his colleagues view as temporarily beaten down.   The portfolio managers and analysts have made some good calls over the years, including asset-management firms like Janus Capital Management (JNS) and T. Rowe Price (TROW); another group, newspaper companies, hasn't panned out as well, thanks to a prolonged advertising slump. One recent laggard holding is McClatchy (MNI), whose shares have lost about one-third of their value this year.   Another reason for the underperformance over three- and five-year horizons for these two funds: Ariel has avoided energy and materials stocks.   Ariel experienced another setback last month: The Masters' Select Smaller Companies Fund's (MSSFX) adviser fired Ariel as a subadviser; Litman/Gregory Fund Advisors did not specify the reason for the move. Morningstar has praised Ariel's approach to investing, noting that it has stuck to its investment style, underperformance notwithstanding. The fund has a three-year annual return of 14.13%, trailing its Morningstar benchmark by about 1 percentage point.   "In the last year, we have started to have a better performance of higher-quality stocks," says Charles Bobrinskoy, director of research at Ariel, who also is portfolio co-manager on the more recently established Ariel Focus Fund (ARFFX). "Until then, lower-quality names and highly leveraged companies did very well."   As of June 30, the Ariel Fund's top holdings included insurance company Markel (MKL); Energizer Holdings (ENR), which has gained about 50% this year, and Mohawk Industries (MHK), whose shares have appreciated by more than 30% year to date.   Another plus for these funds is that they held up well during the bear market earlier this decade, says Todd Trubey, a Morningstar analyst. The Ariel Fund, for example, earned nearly 29% in 2000 and 14.2% in 2001, before losing 5.2% in 2002 -- yet that was stellar compared with the Standard & Poor's 500's loss of 22.1% that year.     Dan Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors newsletter, cautions that a fund Vanguard plans to roll out could be very risky, especially if individual investors try to use it as a way to bet on interest rates.   Vanguard is slated to launch an Extended Duration Treasury Index Fund that caters mainly to institutional investors. Duration measures a bond's sensitivity to changes in interest rates. The longer the duration, the more sensitive it is to rate shifts: When rates rise, a longer-duration bond is vulnerable to a big drop in price, and vice versa.   Wiener worries that the index will attract investors who are unaware or dismissive of just how very volatile this activity can be, and that it can lose them a lot of money in a heartbeat.   Indeed, Vanguard plans for the fund to have three share classes, two for institutional investors. The third will be an exchange-traded fund, which, in theory, any individual investor could put money into via a broker or financial adviser.   Vanguard, however, discloses that "the fund is subject to interest-rate risk, which is the chance that bond prices overall will decline because of rising interest rates."   Rebecca Cohen, a Vanguard spokeswoman, adds that the ETF will cater to financial advisers who work with small pension plans. "We do not think this fund is appropriate for individual investors," says Cohen.   Vanguard says that long-duration bonds help pension funds match their investments with their obligations, which tend to have a long time horizon.   That's the correct use for this fund.   ---   E-mail: lawrence.strauss@barrons.com   ---             Scoreboard     Real Estate Pales, Equity Funds Shine     -- U.S. diversified stock funds rose an average of 1.33% in the week ended Thursday, according to Lipper, the fund-tracking arm of Reuters. The broad market notched a total return of 1.51% in that span. Gold funds had a big week, climbing 4.96%. Real-estate funds lost 1.47%. Headline: Conrad Black Jurors: Insufficient Proof Limited Convictions
Story: CHICAGO (AP)--Jurors who convicted former media baron Conrad Black say the complicated corporate fraud case became easier to understand as prosecutors laid out their evidence, but there wasn't enough evidence to support some charges.   Black, 62, was found guilty Friday on three counts of mail fraud and one count of obstruction of justice for moving documents out of his Toronto office in defiance of a court order. He was acquitted on nine other counts, including the most serious charge of racketeering.   At the outset of the trial, it was difficult to keep track of the different companies involved, said juror Tina Kadisak. But eventually, "you began to understand."   The jury struggled with some of the counts during deliberations but said the prosecution came up short in its argument for the racketeering charge. Juror Monica Prince told the Chicago Sun-Times that there wasn't enough "paper evidence" to support a conviction on that count.   Kadisak said the allegations of racketeering were credible but not backed up by the prosecution.   "There wasn't enough evidence there," the 32-year-old hairdresser told the Chicago Tribune. "Could I see that it happened? Yes...but there wasn't proof of it."   Black was convicted of swindling the Hollinger International newspaper empire he once ran out of millions of dollars. When he was indicted in 2005, prosecutors accused him of bilking shareholders out of $84 million. But during bail discussions that followed the verdict, Black's defense attorneys said he was convicted of stealing $3.5 million.   Three other former Hollinger executives - John Boultbee, 65, of Victoria, B.C.; Peter Y. Atkinson, 60, of Oakville, Ont.; and Mark Kipnis, 59, of Northbrook, Ill. - also were convicted of fraud charges.   Hollinger International, based in Chicago and renamed Sun-Times Media Group Inc. (SVN) last year, was at one time one of the world's largest publishers of community newspapers as well as the Chicago Sun-Times, the Daily Telegraph of London and Israel's Jerusalem Post.   At the core of the charges against Black was a strategy he arrived at starting in 1998 to sell off the bulk of the small community papers, which were published in smaller cities across the United States and Canada.   Black and other Hollinger executives received millions of dollars in payments from the companies that bought the community papers in return for promises that they wouldn't return to compete with the new owners. Prosecutors said the executives pocketed the money, which they said belonged to shareholders, without telling Hollinger's board of directors.   Jurors said they gave little weight to testimony by F. David Radler, the government's star witness. Radler, the Sun-Times' former publisher and Black's partner in building the Hollinger empire over three decades, pleaded guilty to mail fraud and agreed to testify in exchange for a lenient 29-month sentence and a $250,000 fine.   Black had said he was busy with newspaper interests in the U.K. and eastern Canada and left many details to Radler, but Radler said Black was well aware of how and why the money was being paid.   However, Prince said Radler seemed to be looking out for Black.   "He was covering up for his buddy," the juror said. "He didn't really say much. He kept contradicting himself. He was trying to fool the jury. He was just trying to get through it. He was trying to confuse the jury to cover for Black."   Jurors delivered their verdict on the 12th day of deliberations.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 17:25 ET (21:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: S Korea Kia Motors Workers To Continue Strike Next Wk -Report
Story: SEOUL (Dow Jones)--Unionized workers of South Korea's Kia Motors Corp. (000270.SE) will continue to strike for at least eight hours a day next week, except on Tuesday, which is a holiday, online financial news provider Edaily reported Saturday, citing an unnamed Kia union official.   The strike, which began early this week, will lead to production losses of 26,685 vehicles valued at KRW390.5 billion by the end of next week if conducted as scheduled, the report said.   Workers at Kia Motors, which is 38.6% owned by Hyundai Motor Co. (005380.SE), the world's sixth-largest carmaker by sales, are seeking an 8.9% annual raise in basic salary, compared with the previous year's 5.7% increase, a Kia spokesman has said.     By In-Soo Nam, Dow Jones Newswires; 822-721-0583; In-Soo.Nam@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 10:41 ET (14:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) European Trader: A New-And Pricey-Tack For Rio Tinto
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag and Sean Walters   Rio Tinto's knockout counterbid for Alcan is a good use of capital; the acquisition would be a high-quality diversification of the mining company's metals portfolio.   But the premium that Rio Tinto (American depositary share ticker: RTP) is offering, plus the challenge of integrating such a big new business, are sure to leave its shareholders feeling uncomfortable.   For years, Rio Tinto's investors have been spared from shocks. The company has owned top-quality metal reserves, eschewed mega-deals and remained conservatively financed. Yet, many would argue, there have been diminishing returns from this approach. Rio Tinto has sat out $300 billion in metals and mining deals over the past five years. The company, whose strength is in iron ore and copper,  has watched as key nickel and copper miners -- FalconBridge, Inco and WMC -- were bought out by rivals.   All that's about to change.   The agreed-upon $38.1 billion offer, which represents a 66% premium to the share price of Alcan (AL) before the original bid from Alcoa (AA), is the sector's biggest-ever cash deal. (Alcoa's $27.9 billion offer, which now has been withdrawn, was cash and shares.) It puts an enterprise value of $44 billion on Alcan, equivalent to 9.4 times forecast 2007 Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow).   Alcan paid an 8.3 times enterprise-value/Ebitda multiple for aluminum producer Pechiney in 2003, while Xstrata paid 9.2 times for Falconbridge earlier this year. (Enterprise value is stock-market capitalization, plus net debt.)   From a net-debt/Ebitda multiple of 0.2 times at Rio Tinto, the combined company's leverage would jump to 2.5 times. Net debt would rise to $46.3 billion from $2.4 billion. Little wonder that Rio Tinto is calling it a day on share buybacks.   Rio Tinto's desperation to make up for lost time is reflected in the aggressiveness of its $101-a-share bid. A rival offer would have to trump that -- and include $2.71 a share to cover the breakup fee.   Rio Tinto has some natural advantages over Alcoa, which itself now appears to be in play. For one thing, its trans-Atlantic tie-up presents fewer antitrust worries than one involving two North American miners. For another, selling shareholders on such a rich bid should be easier for Rio Tinto than for Alcoa.   The combined debt of Alcoa and Alcan would have been $35 billion. Servicing that debt would have been difficult if a combined Alcoa-Alcan would have had to sell assets to get antitrust approval.   The Alcan deal should provide about $600 million in efficiencies for Rio Tinto by 2010 and should boost earnings within a year after the transaction closes. That should help Rio Tinto win shareholder support for a future rights issue to pay down debt.   Rio Tinto is betting that aluminum prices, up 76% in the past three years, will stay high as demand for the metal rises in India and China. It's important for that to happen, given the extra room for maneuver Rio Tinto might need when it brings so little merger experience to the table, even allowing for Alcan's own strong record on the integration front.     While the subprime-mortgage fiasco has grabbed headlines in the U.S., investors in Europe have a similar worry: "cov-lite" and "cov-loose" loans.   Banks in Europe have become more reluctant to make these loans to private-equity firms, hedge funds and other investors in highly leveraged transactions. Up to 15 deals may be on hold, with lead banks having trouble finding syndicate buyers for portions of the borrowings.   The clearest evidence of the trend appears to be the difficulty Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its primary lenders are having in financing the leveraged buyout of Alliance Boots (AB.U.K.), the British pharmacy chain.   Investors are concerned over the proposed cov-loose nature the GBP 9 billion ($18.25 billion) financing of the Alliance Boots transaction and what they see as inadequate disclosure.   Typically, a cov-lite loan has none of the maintenance convenants that lenders usually demand, and carry only incurrence-based convenants. That is, a borrower's financial ratios are tested only when new debt is incurred, not at regular -- usually quarterly -- intervals.   A cov-loose loan has fewer maintenance convenants than normal.   Reducing or eliminating loan covenants removes a mechanism for lenders to detect early signs of trouble with repayments. Primary lenders aren't very worried because they've been passing on the risk to the secondary market, through derivative obligations. It's the secondary investors who would have to pick up the pieces in a default, just as holders of U.S. collateralized debt obligations backed by subprime loans are learning, to their regret.   ---   Arindam Nag and Sean Walters are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based. Headline: Hyundai Motor Eyes Stake In India's Eicher Motors - Report
Story: NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--South Korean auto maker Hyundai Motor Co. Ltd. (005380.SE) is in talks with Eicher Motors Ltd. (505200.BY) to acquire a stake in the Indian commercial vehicle maker, the Times Of India reported Saturday, quoting a person close to the development.   Hyundai is looking at kick starting its commercial vehicle business in India and doesn't want to wait to build it business from scratch, the industry person, who was not identified, was quoted by the paper as saying.   A Hyundai delegation, which was recently in India, met Eicher officials to look for avenues for collaboration or even a complete buyout, the paper said.   However, a senior Eicher Motors official was quoted by the paper as saying: "We talk to companies in similar business as a matter of routine. It will be speculative to read anything into these discussions."       Newspaper Web Site: http://www.timesofindia.com     -By New Delhi Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 91-11-2307 4020; djn.in@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 07:09 ET (11:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/16) The Big Board's Shrinking World
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   A Hemingway protagonist famously described the two ways he'd gone bankrupt: "Gradually, then suddenly." That also describes how electronic trading encroached on the traditional floor-based dealing on the New York Stock Exchange.   For decades, automatic trade execution made incremental inroads on the human-intermediated transactions handled by Big Board specialists, who were assigned to maintain orderly markets in particular stocks. For years, the NYSE's market share in its own listed stocks bled slowly lower, but only to about 70%. However, in the six months since its Hybrid Market system was fully implemented, enabling more direct electronic order routing, the Big Board's share has sunk to around 50%, though overall volume is up.   And with a new regulatory structure that even further restricts specialists' participation, the profit opportunities for these middlemen have all but evaporated. There was some hope that specialists would be able to secure an ongoing role in trading large, active stocks by encoding their buying and selling interests in algorithms that govern trade execution. But so far, these efforts haven't borne much fruit.   Since December, the NYSE essentially has been subsidizing specialists with direct cash "revenue-sharing" payments. The program, scheduled to last six months, was just extended through Aug. 31. The extension came as specialists were in near-revolt over what they see as a deck stacked against them; the situation even spawned rash talk of a walkout as a protest.   These issues would seem to have spurred last week's announcement that LaBranche & Co. (ticker: LAB) --  one of the the largest specialist firms and the biggest independent one -- would "explore strategic alternatives," presumably a search for possible acquirers.   Barron's handicapped some of these changes in a cover story late last year ("Death of the Floor," Nov. 20, 2006), which argued that regulatory and technological changes would radically shrink the NYSE floor, as the industry chose the speed of electronic trading over the possible pricing advantages of a human-run auction. Since then, brokerage firms have slashed floor-trading staffs, while the exchange closed one of five trading rooms and is rumored to be near to padlocking the doors of one or two more.   Yet we also saw the likelihood of a continuing, smaller role for specialists, as a distinguishing advantage of the NYSE that could help secure listings and help facilitate trading in smaller, less-liquid stocks.   LaBranche, at a recent price of $7.28, has a market value of $449 million. Some $240 million of that can be attributed to its ownership of 2.9 million shares in NYSE parent NYSE Euronext (NYX). Its units that make markets in options and exchange-traded funds should also hold some value. The firm has $500 million in capital that regulators require it to hold against trading positions. The SEC has reduced these requirements incrementally as LaBranche's positions have shrunk, helping it service its $459 million in debt.   The question for investors is whether a potential buyer -- a brokerage house or electronic market-making firm, presumably -- would see any value in the stock-specialist business, if not to turn a profit on its own then to enhance other trading activities. If there is any value, LaBranche should sell for a price above its current one.   In May, Bear Stearns (BSC) wrote down the value of its specialist division by $225 million, an estimated 60% of its prior carrying price. Yet it's telling that Bear simultaneously bought the minority interest in the unit from a partner, even though floor pros said that it had the option of selling this at a better price. Could this mean that some residual value remains in this business?   NYSE Euronext, which went public in 2006 by merging with electronic market Archipelago, is by stated strategy agnostic about whether customers access its market via the floor or through fiberoptic cables alone. Yet on some level, management recognizes that without the floor and its promises of lower volatility, "market color" about trading dynamics and potential price improvement -- things it has trumpeted for years -- the NYSE is just a bigger Nasdaq with a fancy marble building in Lower Manhattan.   To keep its lead in listing big companies, logic suggests that the New York Stock Exchange should find a way to preserve elements of a human-informed auction market as the general trading environment becomes more fragmented.   No matter how these developments go, shares of NYSE Euronext look like a better bet at 83 today than they did above 90 eight months ago. If specialists can find a way to make a buck, it will be because they're making the market more efficient. If not, a more electronic NYSE would have higher margins.   NYSE shares have suffered from expectations that the company, fresh off its purchase of European derivatives exchange Euronext, is hot to buy a U.S. futures mart, such as the InterContinental Exchange (ICE) or Nymex Holdings (NMX). The stock trades at 25 times forecast 2008 earnings, a sizable discount to other exchanges' shares. Lehman Brothers analyst Roger Freeman upgraded NYSE last week to a Buy, arguing that an ICE or Nymex purchase would be minimally dilutive or accretive.   One benefit of a possible deal: Both ICE and Nymex have New York trading floors, which could be efficiently moved into the suddenly vacant expanses of that famous building at Wall and Broad.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Police:14 Tesco Supermkts Closed On Threats To Reopen Soon
Story: LONDON (AP)--U.K. police closed at 14 Tesco PLC (TSCDY) supermarkets across the country Saturday following a series of threats, authorities said. Police said the threats weren't believed to be linked to terrorism.   Police said Tesco planned to reopen the stores as soon as possible, either later Saturday or Sunday.   The manager at a Tesco in Barrhead, near Glasgow, told the U.K.'s Press Association that staff were sent home around 12:30 p.m. (1330 GMT) after a power failure. But an unidentified employee at a neighboring shop said police had told him there had been a bomb threat.   A criminal investigation was being led by police in Hertfordshire, where the U.K.'s largest supermarket chain has its headquarters. Police said no one had been hurt and that the move was a precaution.   "We have no reason to believe that the incidents are linked to extremism of any kind," Hertfordshire police said in a statement.   Tesco confirmed there had been a number of incidents, but gave no details.   "Police are investigating and so we are unable to comment further," she said on condition of anonymity in line with company policy. "As always, at all times customer welfare is our priority."   Police said the closures affected stores in London and other locations in England, Scotland and Wales.   "It was a power failure - that's what all the customers and all the staff were informed of," an employee at a store in Derbyshire, north of London, told British Broadcasting Corp. television by telephone.   "They just said they stopped all the deliveries at the store for the rest of the day," he said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 15:47 ET (19:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : ngi group Announces Capital / Business Partnership with Fractalist, inc.
Story: TOKYO--(BUSINESS WIRE)--July 14, 2007--   Today, ngi group (Satoshi Koike, Representative Executive Officer, President and CEO) (TOKYO:2497) announced the decision to enter into a financial and business partnership with Fractalist, inc. (based in Shibuya-ku, Tokyo; Yusuke Tanaka, Representative Director and President) (Nagoya:3821) with the aim of building a wide-ranging cooperative relationship between Japan and China in the mobile internet field.       Details of Capital / Business Partnership       1. ngi group will underwrite the third-party allocation of shares  scheduled for July 30, 2007 by Fractalist, thereby cementing the  relationship between the two companies.       2. Fractalist and ngi mobile, a subsidiary of ngi group  responsible for mobile business, will merge on December 1, 2007 and  unify business activities.     Fractalist is a specialist in the field of mobile technology and development, with know-how in the creation of mobile content. They provide mobile advertising service, planning and operation, as well as mobile media planning. The merger of the two companies will strengthen planning and development of mobile media by creating a business management infrastructure with the broad reach to include advertising, contents, solutions and mobile services. They will strive to become the leader in the mobile internet business in Japan.     Pending the merger, ngi group will acquire 46.7% of aggregate issued shares of Fractalist, and will make Fractalist a consolidated subsidiary of ngi group.       3. Both ngi group and Fractalist will be acquiring shares of  MEDIAPRO TECHNOLOGY LIMITED, a company financed by Fractalist that is  involved in mobile advertising service in China, and engaging in  activities aimed at expanding MEDIAPRO operations in order to  strengthen relations between the three companies.        CONTACT: ngi group, inc.               Investor Relations Office               Masato Miyawaki, +81-3-5572-6202               ngi-ir@ngigroup.com               http://www.ngigroup.com/        SOURCE: ngi group, inc. Headline: Barron's(7/16) D.C. Current: Crucial Vote On IT Outsourcing
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   Big labor and its democratic allies on Capitol Hill have failed twice in recent months to overcome GOP opposition to pro-union legislation. The third time may be the charm.   There's a major pro-union provision in the farm bill that will be marked up this week by the House Agricultural Committee. It is tailored to kill Indiana Gov. Mitch Daniels' $1.6 billion food-stamp/welfare outsourcing contract with International Business Machines (ticker: IBM), an arrangement that the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees says is being championed by right-wing ideologues at the expense of the needy.   The impact would be felt beyond Indiana. If Afscme and its allies, which include farm groups and nutrition advocates, are successful, that would throw a wet blanket on new outsourcing projects in other states.   Phillip Bond, the president and CEO of the Information Technology Association of America, says that the marketplace potentially is worth "tens of billions of dollars" to private contractors.   Daniels claims that the IBM contract would save Indiana taxpayers $490 million and that canceling it would cost them $100 million. Chuck Loveless, the director of legislative affairs for Afscme, the country's largest public-employees union, says that Daniels is giving IBM incentives to willy-nilly boot people off the food-stamp and welfare rolls. In addition, he contends, the contract might be illegal.   Daniels is an old nemesis of the union. On his first day as governor in 2005, he eliminated collective bargaining for state employees, a right that had been granted by executive order in 1989 by then Gov. Evan Bayh, a Democrat who is now a U.S. senator. Daniels said that the practice prevented him from restructuring government to eliminate waste. About 23,000 state employees joined Afscme and other unions after Bayh signed the order. Daniels' administration claims that 80% dropped their memberships after he negated the collective-bargaining provision.   Loveless says that anyone who views this exclusively as a fight between labor and union-buster Daniels is missing the point: A 1979 federal law says that merit-based public employees must determine who is eligible for food stamps. He accuses Daniels of circumventing that law in order to take budget cutting "to a new, extreme level."   "A lot of work can be done by the private sector like outreach, secretarial work and facilities management," says Loveless. But, he contends, Daniels is outsourcing decision-making that should be left to public servants. The Daniels administration says that all final determinations of food-stamp eligibility are made by state employees who got their positions on merit. IBM employees -- 1,500 of whom used to work for the state's welfare department -- review initial applications to make sure they are in order. The federal law doesn't apply to all activities related to eligibility determinations, asserts Mitch Roob, secretary of Indiana's Family and Social Service Center.   Indiana has ranked first in child deaths and last in getting welfare recipients to work, according to the Daniels administration. Roob says that the program has lacked enough computers to be effective, but that those running it had spent over $1 million on file cabinets last year and another $1 million mailing welfare case files from one office to another. IBM and its partners would digitize the files.   The big showdown in the Agricultural Committee will come this Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday when the markup of the farm bill is scheduled. The 21 Republicans on the committee need the votes of three Democrats to kill the provision favored by the union.   Two Indiana Democrats on the committee are being wooed. At least one of them, Joe Donnelly, a freshman from South Bend who received large political contributions from labor, is leaning against outsourcing. "I have serious reservations about Gov. Daniels' push to turn over to private contractors a significant portion of the state's welfare-eligibility process," he said in a prepared statement for Barron's.   The other Democratic member, Brad Ellsworth from Evansville, didn't return our calls.   After the bill is marked up, it will be voted on by the full House. Companion legislation will be considered by the Senate. On July 9, Republicans blocked language in a homeland-security bill that would have extended union protection to 45,000 federal airport security workers. On June 26, Senate Republicans blocked a "card check" bill that would have let employees certify a union without holding a secret-ballot election.   Doing work for state government is a big business for the information-technology industry. Northrop Grumman in 2005 received a $2 billion contract from Virginia to overhaul the state's data operations. Most states outsource Medicaid processing to private IT firms.   Outsourcing frequently proves controversial. Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush launched three major privatization deals during his term, including a $350 million agreement with Convergys Corp. to manage the state's human-resources operations.   The programs were criticized for going over budget and were plagued with problems. The Sunshine State's current governor, Charlie Crist, has drawn plaudits from the press and public for establishing oversight committees to ride herd on the contractors.   After a pilot program to privatize welfare in three Texas counties led to chaos last year, the state closed it. That fiasco chilled the overall state IT-outsourcing market, says Chris Dixon, an analyst with Input, which collects data on government procurement.   Loveless contends that Daniels is headed down the same path as Texas.   Dixon says defeat of Indiana's program could set the privatization marketplace back two to three years. Ironically, he adds, Democratic governors have been the biggest proponents of outsourcing, with the aim of boosting efficiency and trimming  taxpayers' costs.   Remember Lawrence Lindsey, the former Bush economic guru who was bounced from his job in December 2002, in part for being more honest than politic?   Lindsey publicly predicted that the Iraq war would cost at least $200 billion at a time when the president wasn't even acknowledging that there would be a war. The invasion was launched in March 2003. Since then, the U.S. has spent more than $440 billion on the conflict.   Because of Lindsey's reputation for prescience, we revisited a speech on the housing market that he delivered in April to fellow economists. In it, he said: "Short of the war on terrorism, this is by far the greatest risk posed to the American economy and our way of life."   The problem isn't just that house prices appear to be in a sustained decline. Congress and the regulators are reacting in knee-jerk fashion to avenge first-time home buyers facing foreclosure. That's scaring already panicked lenders into tightening credit even more.   Congress, which Lindsey argues helped create the bubble by increasing access to homeownership through the Community Reinvestment Act, now, through hearings and the threat legislation directed at the mortgage business, is reducing the supply of financing to first-time buyers. Lindsey said it's similar to what bankers called the "regulatory reign of terror" that caused real-estate collapses in Texas, Colorado, California and New England in the late 1980s. "In 1991, spending on residential construction amounted to just 3.4% of GDP, down from a peak of 5.0 in 1987," Lindsey recalled.   This time, he predicted, the cycle will be exacerbated because losses on mortgage securities will be higher than anticipated, causing buyers of these instruments to pull back from the market. Legal risks posed by trial lawyers representing "innocent victims" will make it even worse, he said. "Given the widespread standard of joint and several liability, the one who will pay the punitive damages will not be the original issuer -- who may be bankrupt by that time -- but the buyer of that paper," Lindsey asserted.   He would have President Bush, Congress and the Federal Reserve take steps that would assure investors that they won't be sued for simply investing.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Chinese Imperial Palace Shuts Down Starbucks
Story: BEIJING (AP)--China's imperial palace has closed its Starbucks outlet following protests led by a state TV personality against the coffeehouse's presence at a major Chinese cultural site, news reports said Saturday.   The small outlet, a popular resting spot for visitors to the sprawling Forbidden City in central Beijing, closed Friday afternoon, the Beijing Morning Post and other newspapers reported.   The Starbucks opened in 2000 at the invitation of palace managers, but critics said it was inappropriate for the site.   Palace managers offered Starbucks the option of continuing to operate as part of a combined coffeehouse with other brands but the Seattle-based company declined, the Post said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 14, 2007 01:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
